Parsing [sent. 23 len. 100]: In consideration of the day and hour of my birth , it was declared by the nurse , and by some sage women in the neighbourhood who had taken a lively interest in me several months before there was any possibility of our becoming personally acquainted , first , that I was destined to be unlucky in life ; and secondly , that I was privileged to see ghosts and spirits ; both these gifts inevitably attaching , as they believed , to all unlucky infants of either gender , born towards the small hours on a Friday night .

Parsing [sent. 27 len. 25]: I was born with a caul , which was advertised for sale , in the newspapers , at the low price of fifteen guineas .
Parsing [sent. 28 len. 76]: Whether sea-going people were short of money about that time , or were short of faith and preferred cork jackets , I do n't know ; all I know is , that there was but one solitary bidding , and that was from an attorney connected with the bill-broking business , who offered two pounds in cash , and the balance in sherry , but declined to be guaranteed from drowning on any higher bargain .
Parsing [sent. 29 len. 64]: Consequently the advertisement was withdrawn at a dead loss -- for as to sherry , my poor dear mother 's own sherry was in the market then -- and ten years afterwards , the caul was put up in a raffle down in our part of the country , to fifty members at half-a-crown a head , the winner to spend five shillings .

Parsing [sent. 216 len. 48]: Mr. Chillip , looking mildly at my aunt with his head on one side , and making her a little bow , said , in allusion to the jewellers ' cotton , as he softly touched his left ear : ` Some local irritation , ma'am ? '

Parsing [sent. 218 len. 15]: replied my aunt , pulling the cotton out of one ear like a cork .

Parsing [sent. 220 len. 13]: But he repeated sweetly : ` Some local irritation , ma'am ? '

Parsing [sent. 241 len. 25]: He preferred to go and sit upon the stairs , in the dark and a strong draught , until he was again sent for .
Parsing [sent. 242 len. 76]: Ham Peggotty , who went to the national school , and was a very dragon at his catechism , and who may therefore be regarded as a credible witness , reported next day , that happening to peep in at the parlour-door an hour after this , he was instantly descried by Miss Betsey , then walking to and fro in a state of agitation , and pounced upon before he could make his escape .
Parsing [sent. 243 len. 47]: That there were now occasional sounds of feet and voices overhead which he inferred the cotton did not exclude , from the circumstance of his evidently being clutched by the lady as a victim on whom to expend her superabundant agitation when the sounds were loudest .

Parsing [sent. 279 len. 80]: I lay in my basket , and my mother lay in her bed ; but Betsey Trotwood Copperfield was for ever in the land of dreams and shadows , the tremendous region whence I had so lately travelled ; and the light upon the window of our room shone out upon the earthly bourne of all such travellers , and the mound above the ashes and the dust that once was he , without whom I had never been .
Parsing [sent. 280 len. 85]: Chapter 2 I Observe The first objects that assume a distinct presence before me , as I look far back , into the blank of my infancy , are my mother with her pretty hair and youthful shape , and Peggotty with no shape at all , and eyes so dark that they seemed to darken their whole neighbourhood in her face , and cheeks and arms so hard and red that I wondered the birds did n't peck her in preference to apples .
Parsing [sent. 281 len. 37]: I believe I can remember these two at a little distance apart , dwarfed to my sight by stooping down or kneeling on the floor , and I going unsteadily from the one to the other .
Parsing [sent. 282 len. 46]: I have an impression on my mind which I can not distinguish from actual remembrance , of the touch of Peggotty 's forefinger as she used to hold it out to me , and of its being roughened by needlework , like a pocket nutmeg-grater .
Parsing [sent. 283 len. 51]: This may be fancy , though I think the memory of most of us can go farther back into such times than many of us suppose ; just as I believe the power of observation in numbers of very young children to be quite wonderful for its closeness and accuracy .
Parsing [sent. 284 len. 70]: Indeed , I think that most grown men who are remarkable in this respect , may with greater propriety be said not to have lost the faculty , than to have acquired it ; the rather , as I generally observe such men to retain a certain freshness , and gentleness , and capacity of being pleased , which are also an inheritance they have preserved from their childhood .
Parsing [sent. 285 len. 86]: I might have a misgiving that I am ` meandering ' in stopping to say this , but that it brings me to remark that I build these conclusions , in part upon my own experience of myself ; and if it should appear from anything I may set down in this narrative that I was a child of close observation , or that as a man I have a strong memory of my childhood , I undoubtedly lay claim to both of these characteristics .
Parsing [sent. 286 len. 38]: Looking back , as I was saying , into the blank of my infancy , the first objects I can remember as standing out by themselves from a confusion of things , are my mother and Peggotty .
Parsing [sent. 287 len. 6]: What else do I remember ?
Parsing [sent. 288 len. 4]: Let me see .
Parsing [sent. 289 len. 24]: There comes out of the cloud , our house -- not new to me , but quite familiar , in its earliest remembrance .
Parsing [sent. 290 len. 66]: On the ground-floor is Peggotty 's kitchen , opening into a back yard ; with a pigeon-house on a pole , in the centre , without any pigeons in it ; a great dog - kennel in a corner , without any dog ; and a quantity of fowls that look terribly tall to me , walking about , in a menacing and ferocious manner .
Parsing [sent. 291 len. 40]: There is one cock who gets upon a post to crow , and seems to take particular notice of me as I look at him through the kitchen window , who makes me shiver , he is so fierce .
Parsing [sent. 292 len. 40]: Of the geese outside the side-gate who come waddling after me with their long necks stretched out when I go that way , I dream at night : as a man environed by wild beasts might dream of lions .
Parsing [sent. 293 len. 15]: Here is a long passage -- what an enormous perspective I make of it !
Parsing [sent. 294 len. 11]: - leading from Peggotty 's kitchen to the front door .
Parsing [sent. 295 len. 81]: A dark store-room opens out of it , and that is a place to be run past at night ; for I do n't know what may be among those tubs and jars and old tea-chests , when there is nobody in there with a dimly-burning light , letting a mouldy air come out of the door , in which there is the smell of soap , pickles , pepper , candles , and coffee , all at one whiff .
Parsing [sent. 296 len. 59]: Then there are the two parlours : the parlour in which we sit of an evening , my mother and I and Peggotty -- for Peggotty is quite our companion , when her work is done and we are alone -- and the best parlour where we sit on a Sunday ; grandly , but not so comfortably .
Parsing [sent. 297 len. 46]: There is something of a doleful air about that room to me , for Peggotty has told me -- I do n't know when , but apparently ages ago -- about my father 's funeral , and the company having their black cloaks put on .
Parsing [sent. 298 len. 22]: One Sunday night my mother reads to Peggotty and me in there , how Lazarus was raised up from the dead .
Parsing [sent. 299 len. 45]: And I am so frightened that they are afterwards obliged to take me out of bed , and show me the quiet churchyard out of the bedroom window , with the dead all lying in their graves at rest , below the solemn moon .
Parsing [sent. 300 len. 34]: There is nothing half so green that I know anywhere , as the grass of that churchyard ; nothing half so shady as its trees ; nothing half so quiet as its tombstones .
Parsing [sent. 301 len. 69]: The sheep are feeding there , when I kneel up , early in the morning , in my little bed in a closet within my mother 's room , to look out at it ; and I see the red light shining on the sun-dial , and think within myself , ` Is the sun-dial glad , I wonder , that it can tell the time again ? Parsing [sent. 302 len. 8]: Here is our pew in the church .
Parsing [sent. 303 len. 5]: What a high-backed pew !
Parsing [sent. 304 len. 52]: With a window near it , out of which our house can be seen , and IS seen many times during the morning 's service , by Peggotty , who likes to make herself as sure as she can that it 's not being robbed , or is not in flames .

Parsing [sent. 311 len. 29]: I feel that if I looked at him any longer , I might be tempted to say something out loud ; and what would become of me then !

Parsing [sent. 315 len. 51]: In time my eyes gradually shut up ; and , from seeming to hear the clergyman singing a drowsy song in the heat , I hear nothing , until I fall off the seat with a crash , and am taken out , more dead than alive , by Peggotty .
Parsing [sent. 316 len. 44]: And now I see the outside of our house , with the latticed bedroom-windows standing open to let in the sweet-smelling air , and the ragged old rooks ' - nests still dangling in the elm-trees at the bottom of the front garden .
Parsing [sent. 317 len. 91]: Now I am in the garden at the back , beyond the yard where the empty pigeon-house and dog-kennel are -- a very preserve of butterflies , as I remember it , with a high fence , and a gate and padlock ; where the fruit clusters on the trees , riper and richer than fruit has ever been since , in any other garden , and where my mother gathers some in a basket , while I stand by , bolting furtive gooseberries , and trying to look unmoved .
Parsing [sent. 318 len. 14]: A great wind rises , and the summer is gone in a moment .
Parsing [sent. 319 len. 13]: We are playing in the winter twilight , dancing about the parlour .

Parsing [sent. 425 len. 10]: I dare say you 'd quite enjoy it . '
Parsing [sent. 426 len. 14]: Peggotty seemed to take this aspersion very much to heart , I thought .
Parsing [sent. 427 len. 30]: ` And my dear boy , ' cried my mother , coming to the elbow-chair in which I was , and caressing me , ` my own little Davy !
Parsing [sent. 428 len. 27]: Is it to be hinted to me that I am wanting in affection for my precious treasure , the dearest little fellow that ever was ! '
Parsing [sent. 429 len. 15]: ` Nobody never went and hinted no such a thing , ' said Peggotty .
Parsing [sent. 430 len. 7]: ` You did , Peggotty ! '

Parsing [sent. 434 len. 7]: You know it is , Peggotty .

Parsing [sent. 442 len. 25]: I was quite heart-broken myself , and am afraid that in the first transports of wounded tenderness I called Peggotty a ` Beast ' .
Parsing [sent. 443 len. 56]: That honest creature was in deep affliction , I remember , and must have become quite buttonless on the occasion ; for a little volley of those explosives went off , when , after having made it up with my mother , she kneeled down by the elbow-chair , and made it up with me .
Parsing [sent. 444 len. 7]: We went to bed greatly dejected .
Parsing [sent. 445 len. 38]: My sobs kept waking me , for a long time ; and when one very strong sob quite hoisted me up in bed , I found my mother sitting on the coverlet , and leaning over me .
Parsing [sent. 446 len. 14]: I fell asleep in her arms , after that , and slept soundly .

Parsing [sent. 452 len. 36]: She begged him to choose it for himself , but he refused to do that -- I could not understand why -- so she plucked it for him , and gave it into his hand .
Parsing [sent. 453 len. 37]: He said he would never , never part with it any more ; and I thought he must be quite a fool not to know that it would fall to pieces in a day or two .
Parsing [sent. 454 len. 18]: Peggotty began to be less with us , of an evening , than she had always been .
Parsing [sent. 455 len. 44]: My mother deferred to her very much -- more than usual , it occurred to me -- and we were all three excellent friends ; still we were different from what we used to be , and were not so comfortable among ourselves .
Parsing [sent. 456 len. 50]: Sometimes I fancied that Peggotty perhaps objected to my mother 's wearing all the pretty dresses she had in her drawers , or to her going so often to visit at that neighbour 's ; but I could n't , to my satisfaction , make out how it was .

Parsing [sent. 461 len. 31]: One autumn morning I was with my mother in the front garden , when Mr. Murdstone -- I knew him by that name now -- came by , on horseback .
Parsing [sent. 462 len. 46]: He reined up his horse to salute my mother , and said he was going to Lowestoft to see some friends who were there with a yacht , and merrily proposed to take me on the saddle before him if I would like the ride .
Parsing [sent. 463 len. 42]: The air was so clear and pleasant , and the horse seemed to like the idea of the ride so much himself , as he stood snorting and pawing at the garden-gate , that I had a great desire to go .
Parsing [sent. 464 len. 62]: So I was sent upstairs to Peggotty to be made spruce ; and in the meantime Mr. Murdstone dismounted , and , with his horse 's bridle drawn over his arm , walked slowly up and down on the outer side of the sweetbriar fence , while my mother walked slowly up and down on the inner to keep him company .
Parsing [sent. 465 len. 62]: I recollect Peggotty and I peeping out at them from my little window ; I recollect how closely they seemed to be examining the sweetbriar between them , as they strolled along ; and how , from being in a perfectly angelic temper , Peggotty turned cross in a moment , and brushed my hair the wrong way , excessively hard .
Parsing [sent. 466 len. 22]: Mr. Murdstone and I were soon off , and trotting along on the green turf by the side of the road .
Parsing [sent. 467 len. 46]: He held me quite easily with one arm , and I do n't think I was restless usually ; but I could not make up my mind to sit in front of him without turning my head sometimes , and looking up in his face .
Parsing [sent. 468 len. 57]: He had that kind of shallow black eye -- I want a better word to express an eye that has no depth in it to be looked into -- which , when it is abstracted , seems from some peculiarity of light to be disfigured , for a moment at a time , by a cast .
Parsing [sent. 469 len. 28]: Several times when I glanced at him , I observed that appearance with a sort of awe , and wondered what he was thinking about so closely .
Parsing [sent. 470 len. 24]: His hair and whiskers were blacker and thicker , looked at so near , than even I had given them credit for being .
Parsing [sent. 471 len. 40]: A squareness about the lower part of his face , and the dotted indication of the strong black beard he shaved close every day , reminded me of the wax-work that had travelled into our neighbourhood some half-a-year before .
Parsing [sent. 472 len. 29]: This , his regular eyebrows , and the rich white , and black , and brown , of his complexion -- confound his complexion , and his memory !
Parsing [sent. 473 len. 17]: -- made me think him , in spite of my misgivings , a very handsome man .
Parsing [sent. 474 len. 14]: I have no doubt that my poor dear mother thought him so too .
Parsing [sent. 475 len. 21]: We went to an hotel by the sea , where two gentlemen were smoking cigars in a room by themselves .

Parsing [sent. 579 len. 8]: The day soon came for our going .
Parsing [sent. 580 len. 49]: It was such an early day that it came soon , even to me , who was in a fever of expectation , and half afraid that an earthquake or a fiery mountain , or some other great convulsion of nature , might interpose to stop the expedition .
Parsing [sent. 581 len. 18]: We were to go in a carrier 's cart , which departed in the morning after breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 582 len. 24]: I would have given any money to have been allowed to wrap myself up over-night , and sleep in my hat and boots .
Parsing [sent. 583 len. 37]: It touches me nearly now , although I tell it lightly , to recollect how eager I was to leave my happy home ; to think how little I suspected what I did leave for ever .

Parsing [sent. 587 len. 24]: I am glad to dwell upon the earnestness and love with which she lifted up her face to mine , and did so .

Parsing [sent. 590 len. 28]: Peggotty , who was also looking back on the other side , seemed anything but satisfied ; as the face she brought back in the cart denoted .
Parsing [sent. 591 len. 51]: I sat looking at Peggotty for some time , in a reverie on this supposititious case : whether , if she were employed to lose me like the boy in the fairy tale , I should be able to track my way home again by the buttons she would shed .
Parsing [sent. 592 len. 46]: Chapter 3 I have a Change The carrier 's horse was the laziest horse in the world , I should hope , and shuffled along , with his head down , as if he liked to keep people waiting to whom the packages were directed .
Parsing [sent. 593 len. 26]: I fancied , indeed , that he sometimes chuckled audibly over this reflection , but the carrier said he was only troubled with a cough .
Parsing [sent. 594 len. 35]: The carrier had a way of keeping his head down , like his horse , and of drooping sleepily forward as he drove , with one of his arms on each of his knees .
Parsing [sent. 595 len. 45]: I say ` drove ' , but it struck me that the cart would have gone to Yarmouth quite as well without him , for the horse did all that ; and as to conversation , he had no idea of it but whistling .
Parsing [sent. 596 len. 30]: Peggotty had a basket of refreshments on her knee , which would have lasted us out handsomely , if we had been going to London by the same conveyance .
Parsing [sent. 597 len. 12]: We ate a good deal , and slept a good deal .
Parsing [sent. 598 len. 46]: Peggotty always went to sleep with her chin upon the handle of the basket , her hold of which never relaxed ; and I could not have believed unless I had heard her do it , that one defenceless woman could have snored so much .
Parsing [sent. 599 len. 44]: We made so many deviations up and down lanes , and were such a long time delivering a bedstead at a public-house , and calling at other places , that I was quite tired , and very glad , when we saw Yarmouth .
Parsing [sent. 600 len. 57]: It looked rather spongy and soppy , I thought , as I carried my eye over the great dull waste that lay across the river ; and I could not help wondering , if the world were really as round as my geography book said , how any part of it came to be so flat .
Parsing [sent. 601 len. 20]: But I reflected that Yarmouth might be situated at one of the poles ; which would account for it .
Parsing [sent. 602 len. 78]: As we drew a little nearer , and saw the whole adjacent prospect lying a straight low line under the sky , I hinted to Peggotty that a mound or so might have improved it ; and also that if the land had been a little more separated from the sea , and the town and the tide had not been quite so much mixed up , like toast and water , it would have been nicer .
Parsing [sent. 603 len. 37]: But Peggotty said , with greater emphasis than usual , that we must take things as we found them , and that , for her part , she was proud to call herself a Yarmouth Bloater .
Parsing [sent. 604 len. 113]: When we got into the street -LRB- which was strange enough to me -RRB- and smelt the fish , and pitch , and oakum , and tar , and saw the sailors walking about , and the carts jingling up and down over the stones , I felt that I had done so busy a place an injustice ; and said as much to Peggotty , who heard my expressions of delight with great complacency , and told me it was well known -LRB- I suppose to those who had the good fortune to be born Bloaters -RRB- that Yarmouth was , upon the whole , the finest place in the universe .
Parsing [sent. 605 len. 7]: ` Here 's my Am ! '
Parsing [sent. 606 len. 10]: screamed Peggotty , ` growed out of knowledge ! '
Parsing [sent. 607 len. 26]: He was waiting for us , in fact , at the public-house ; and asked me how I found myself , like an old acquaintance .
Parsing [sent. 608 len. 43]: I did not feel , at first , that I knew him as well as he knew me , because he had never come to our house since the night I was born , and naturally he had the advantage of me .
Parsing [sent. 609 len. 18]: But our intimacy was much advanced by his taking me on his back to carry me home .
Parsing [sent. 610 len. 41]: He was , now , a huge , strong fellow of six feet high , broad in proportion , and round-shouldered ; but with a simpering boy 's face and curly light hair that gave him quite a sheepish look .
Parsing [sent. 611 len. 32]: He was dressed in a canvas jacket , and a pair of such very stiff trousers that they would have stood quite as well alone , without any legs in them .
Parsing [sent. 612 len. 30]: And you could n't so properly have said he wore a hat , as that he was covered in a-top , like an old building , with something pitchy .
Parsing [sent. 613 len. 111]: Ham carrying me on his back and a small box of ours under his arm , and Peggotty carrying another small box of ours , we turned down lanes bestrewn with bits of chips and little hillocks of sand , and went past gas-works , rope-walks , boat-builders ' yards , shipwrights ' yards , ship-breakers ' yards , caulkers ' yards , riggers ' lofts , smiths ' forges , and a great litter of such places , until we came out upon the dull waste I had already seen at a distance ; when Ham said , ` Yon 's our house , Mas ' r Davy ! '
Parsing [sent. 614 len. 36]: I looked in all directions , as far as I could stare over the wilderness , and away at the sea , and away at the river , but no house could I make out .
Parsing [sent. 615 len. 56]: There was a black barge , or some other kind of superannuated boat , not far off , high and dry on the ground , with an iron funnel sticking out of it for a chimney and smoking very cosily ; but nothing else in the way of a habitation that was visible to me .
Parsing [sent. 616 len. 7]: ` That 's not it ? '
Parsing [sent. 617 len. 8]: said I. ` That ship-looking thing ? '
Parsing [sent. 618 len. 14]: ` That 's it , Mas ' r Davy , ' returned Ham .
Parsing [sent. 619 len. 32]: If it had been Aladdin 's palace , roc 's egg and all , I suppose I could not have been more charmed with the romantic idea of living in it .
Parsing [sent. 620 len. 65]: There was a delightful door cut in the side , and it was roofed in , and there were little windows in it ; but the wonderful charm of it was , that it was a real boat which had no doubt been upon the water hundreds of times , and which had never been intended to be lived in , on dry land .
Parsing [sent. 621 len. 9]: That was the captivation of it to me .
Parsing [sent. 622 len. 40]: If it had ever been meant to be lived in , I might have thought it small , or inconvenient , or lonely ; but never having been designed for any such use , it became a perfect abode .
Parsing [sent. 623 len. 12]: It was beautifully clean inside , and as tidy as possible .
Parsing [sent. 624 len. 51]: There was a table , and a Dutch clock , and a chest of drawers , and on the chest of drawers there was a tea-tray with a painting on it of a lady with a parasol , taking a walk with a military-looking child who was trundling a hoop .
Parsing [sent. 625 len. 41]: The tray was kept from tumbling down , by a bible ; and the tray , if it had tumbled down , would have smashed a quantity of cups and saucers and a teapot that were grouped around the book .
Parsing [sent. 626 len. 48]: On the walls there were some common coloured pictures , framed and glazed , of scripture subjects ; such as I have never seen since in the hands of pedlars , without seeing the whole interior of Peggotty 's brother 's house again , at one view .

Parsing [sent. 1269 len. 35]: I never shall forget the waking , next morning ; the being cheerful and fresh for the first moment , and then the being weighed down by the stale and dismal oppression of remembrance .
Parsing [sent. 1270 len. 52]: Miss Murdstone reappeared before I was out of bed ; told me , in so many words , that I was free to walk in the garden for half an hour and no longer ; and retired , leaving the door open , that I might avail myself of that permission .
Parsing [sent. 1271 len. 18]: I did so , and did so every morning of my imprisonment , which lasted five days .
Parsing [sent. 1272 len. 97]: If I could have seen my mother alone , I should have gone down on my knees to her and besought her forgiveness ; but I saw no one , Miss Murdstone excepted , during the whole time -- except at evening prayers in the parlour ; to which I was escorted by Miss Murdstone after everybody else was placed ; where I was stationed , a young outlaw , all alone by myself near the door ; and whence I was solemnly conducted by my jailer , before any one arose from the devotional posture .
Parsing [sent. 1273 len. 45]: I only observed that my mother was as far off from me as she could be , and kept her face another way so that I never saw it ; and that Mr. Murdstone 's hand was bound up in a large linen wrapper .
Parsing [sent. 1274 len. 16]: The length of those five days I can convey no idea of to any one .
Parsing [sent. 1275 len. 10]: They occupy the place of years in my remembrance .
Parsing [sent. 1276 len. 268]: The way in which I listened to all the incidents of the house that made themselves audible to me ; the ringing of bells , the opening and shutting of doors , the murmuring of voices , the footsteps on the stairs ; to any laughing , whistling , or singing , outside , which seemed more dismal than anything else to me in my solitude and disgrace -- the uncertain pace of the hours , especially at night , when I would wake thinking it was morning , and find that the family were not yet gone to bed , and that all the length of night had yet to come -- the depressed dreams and nightmares I had -- the return of day , noon , afternoon , evening , when the boys played in the churchyard , and I watched them from a distance within the room , being ashamed to show myself at the window lest they should know I was a prisoner -- the strange sensation of never hearing myself speak -- the fleeting intervals of something like cheerfulness , which came with eating and drinking , and went away with it -- the setting in of rain one evening , with a fresh smell , and its coming down faster and faster between me and the church , until it and gathering night seemed to quench me in gloom , and fear , and remorse -- all this appears to have gone round and round for years instead of days , it is so vividly and strongly stamped on my remembrance .

Parsing [sent. 1673 len. 77]: I do n't know what the tunes were -- if there were such things in the performance at all , which I doubt -- but the influence of the strain upon me was , first , to make me think of all my sorrows until I could hardly keep my tears back ; then to take away my appetite ; and lastly , to make me so sleepy that I could n't keep my eyes open .

Parsing [sent. 1708 len. 40]: A bird , in a cage very little bigger than himself , makes a mournful rattle now and then in hopping on his perch , two inches high , or dropping from it ; but neither sings nor chirps .
Parsing [sent. 1709 len. 23]: There is a strange unwholesome smell upon the room , like mildewed corduroys , sweet apples wanting air , and rotten books .
Parsing [sent. 1710 len. 42]: There could not well be more ink splashed about it , if it had been roofless from its first construction , and the skies had rained , snowed , hailed , and blown ink through the varying seasons of the year .
Parsing [sent. 1711 len. 32]: Mr. Mell having left me while he took his irreparable boots upstairs , I went softly to the upper end of the room , observing all this as I crept along .
Parsing [sent. 1712 len. 29]: Suddenly I came upon a pasteboard placard , beautifully written , which was lying on the desk , and bore these words : ` TAKE CARE OF HIM .
Parsing [sent. 1713 len. 4]: HE BITES . '
Parsing [sent. 1714 len. 16]: I got upon the desk immediately , apprehensive of at least a great dog underneath .
Parsing [sent. 1715 len. 18]: But , though I looked all round with anxious eyes , I could see nothing of him .
Parsing [sent. 1716 len. 24]: I was still engaged in peering about , when Mr. Mell came back , and asked me what I did up there ? '
Parsing [sent. 1717 len. 24]: I beg your pardon , sir , ' says I , ` if you please , I 'm looking for the dog . '
Parsing [sent. 1718 len. 4]: ` Dog ? '
Parsing [sent. 1719 len. 3]: he says .
Parsing [sent. 1720 len. 5]: ` What dog ? '
Parsing [sent. 1721 len. 10]: ` Is n't it a dog , sir ? '
Parsing [sent. 1722 len. 8]: ` Is n't what a dog ? '
Parsing [sent. 1723 len. 15]: ` That 's to be taken care of , sir ; that bites . '
Parsing [sent. 1724 len. 18]: ` No , Copperfield , ' says he , gravely , ` that 's not a dog .
Parsing [sent. 1725 len. 5]: That 's a boy .
Parsing [sent. 1726 len. 14]: My instructions are , Copperfield , to put this placard on your back .
Parsing [sent. 1727 len. 18]: I am sorry to make such a beginning with you , but I must do it . '
Parsing [sent. 1728 len. 42]: With that he took me down , and tied the placard , which was neatly constructed for the purpose , on my shoulders like a knapsack ; and wherever I went , afterwards , I had the consolation of carrying it .
Parsing [sent. 1729 len. 11]: What I suffered from that placard , nobody can imagine .
Parsing [sent. 1730 len. 21]: Whether it was possible for people to see me or not , I always fancied that somebody was reading it .
Parsing [sent. 1731 len. 25]: It was no relief to turn round and find nobody ; for wherever my back was , there I imagined somebody always to be .
Parsing [sent. 1732 len. 11]: That cruel man with the wooden leg aggravated my sufferings .
Parsing [sent. 1733 len. 42]: He was in authority ; and if he ever saw me leaning against a tree , or a wall , or the house , he roared out from his lodge door in a stupendous voice , ` Hallo , you sir !
Parsing [sent. 1734 len. 3]: You Copperfield !
Parsing [sent. 1735 len. 12]: Show that badge conspicuous , or I 'll report you ! '
Parsing [sent. 1736 len. 105]: The playground was a bare gravelled yard , open to all the back of the house and the offices ; and I knew that the servants read it , and the butcher read it , and the baker read it ; that everybody , in a word , who came backwards and forwards to the house , of a morning when I was ordered to walk there , read that I was to be taken care of , for I bit , I recollect that I positively began to have a dread of myself , as a kind of wild boy who did bite .
Parsing [sent. 1737 len. 21]: There was an old door in this playground , on which the boys had a custom of carving their names .
Parsing [sent. 1738 len. 8]: It was completely covered with such inscriptions .
Parsing [sent. 1739 len. 42]: In my dread of the end of the vacation and their coming back , I could not read a boy 's name , without inquiring in what tone and with what emphasis HE would read , ` Take care of him .
Parsing [sent. 1740 len. 4]: He bites . '
Parsing [sent. 1741 len. 40]: There was one boy -- a certain J. Steerforth -- who cut his name very deep and very often , who , I conceived , would read it in a rather strong voice , and afterwards pull my hair .
Parsing [sent. 1742 len. 27]: There was another boy , one Tommy Traddles , who I dreaded would make game of it , and pretend to be dreadfully frightened of me .
Parsing [sent. 1743 len. 15]: There was a third , George Demple , who I fancied would sing it .
Parsing [sent. 1744 len. 62]: I have looked , a little shrinking creature , at that door , until the owners of all the names -- there were five-and-forty of them in the school then , Mr. Mell said -- seemed to send me to Coventry by general acclamation , and to cry out , each in his own way , ` Take care of him .
Parsing [sent. 1745 len. 4]: He bites ! '
Parsing [sent. 1746 len. 13]: It was the same with the places at the desks and forms .
Parsing [sent. 1747 len. 29]: It was the same with the groves of deserted bedsteads I peeped at , on my way to , and when I was in , my own bed .
Parsing [sent. 1748 len. 76]: I remember dreaming night after night , of being with my mother as she used to be , or of going to a party at Mr. Peggotty 's , or of travelling outside the stage-coach , or of dining again with my unfortunate friend the waiter , and in all these circumstances making people scream and stare , by the unhappy disclosure that I had nothing on but my little night-shirt , and that placard .
Parsing [sent. 1749 len. 26]: In the monotony of my life , and in my constant apprehension of the re-opening of the school , it was such an insupportable affliction !
Parsing [sent. 1750 len. 33]: I had long tasks every day to do with Mr. Mell ; but I did them , there being no Mr. and Miss Murdstone here , and got through them without disgrace .
Parsing [sent. 1751 len. 25]: Before , and after them , I walked about -- supervised , as I have mentioned , by the man with the wooden leg .
Parsing [sent. 1752 len. 58]: How vividly I call to mind the damp about the house , the green cracked flagstones in the court , an old leaky water-butt , and the discoloured trunks of some of the grim trees , which seemed to have dripped more in the rain than other trees , and to have blown less in the sun !
Parsing [sent. 1753 len. 30]: At one we dined , Mr. Mell and I , at the upper end of a long bare dining-room , full of deal tables , and smelling of fat .
Parsing [sent. 1754 len. 27]: Then , we had more tasks until tea , which Mr. Mell drank out of a blue teacup , and I out of a tin pot .
Parsing [sent. 1755 len. 54]: All day long , and until seven or eight in the evening , Mr. Mell , at his own detached desk in the schoolroom , worked hard with pen , ink , ruler , books , and writing - paper , making out the bills -LRB- as I found -RRB- for last half-year .
Parsing [sent. 1756 len. 47]: When he had put up his things for the night he took out his flute , and blew at it , until I almost thought he would gradually blow his whole being into the large hole at the top , and ooze away at the keys .
Parsing [sent. 1757 len. 33]: I picture my small self in the dimly-lighted rooms , sitting with my head upon my hand , listening to the doleful performance of Mr. Mell , and conning tomorrow 's lessons .
Parsing [sent. 1758 len. 49]: I picture myself with my books shut up , still listening to the doleful performance of Mr. Mell , and listening through it to what used to be at home , and to the blowing of the wind on Yarmouth flats , and feeling very sad and solitary .
Parsing [sent. 1759 len. 26]: I picture myself going up to bed , among the unused rooms , and sitting on my bed-side crying for a comfortable word from Peggotty .
Parsing [sent. 1760 len. 86]: I picture myself coming downstairs in the morning , and looking through a long ghastly gash of a staircase window at the school-bell hanging on the top of an out-house with a weathercock above it ; and dreading the time when it shall ring J. Steerforth and the rest to work : which is only second , in my foreboding apprehensions , to the time when the man with the wooden leg shall unlock the rusty gate to give admission to the awful Mr. Creakle .
Parsing [sent. 1761 len. 30]: I can not think I was a very dangerous character in any of these aspects , but in all of them I carried the same warning on my back .
Parsing [sent. 1762 len. 16]: Mr. Mell never said much to me , but he was never harsh to me .
Parsing [sent. 1763 len. 12]: I suppose we were company to each other , without talking .
Parsing [sent. 1764 len. 34]: I forgot to mention that he would talk to himself sometimes , and grin , and clench his fist , and grind his teeth , and pull his hair in an unaccountable manner .
Parsing [sent. 1765 len. 21]: But he had these peculiarities : and at first they frightened me , though I soon got used to them .
Parsing [sent. 1766 len. 53]: Chapter 6 I Enlarge My Circle of Acquaintance I HAD led this life about a month , when the man with the wooden leg began to stump about with a mop and a bucket of water , from which I inferred that preparations were making to receive Mr. Creakle and the boys .
Parsing [sent. 1767 len. 87]: I was not mistaken ; for the mop came into the schoolroom before long , and turned out Mr. Mell and me , who lived where we could , and got on how we could , for some days , during which we were always in the way of two or three young women , who had rarely shown themselves before , and were so continually in the midst of dust that I sneezed almost as much as if Salem House had been a great snuff-box .
Parsing [sent. 1768 len. 17]: One day I was informed by Mr. Mell that Mr. Creakle would be home that evening .
Parsing [sent. 1769 len. 14]: In the evening , after tea , I heard that he was come .
Parsing [sent. 1770 len. 18]: Before bedtime , I was fetched by the man with the wooden leg to appear before him .
Parsing [sent. 1771 len. 61]: Mr. Creakle 's part of the house was a good deal more comfortable than ours , and he had a snug bit of garden that looked pleasant after the dusty playground , which was such a desert in miniature , that I thought no one but a camel , or a dromedary , could have felt at home in it .
Parsing [sent. 1772 len. 93]: It seemed to me a bold thing even to take notice that the passage looked comfortable , as I went on my way , trembling , to Mr. Creakle 's presence : which so abashed me , when I was ushered into it , that I hardly saw Mrs. Creakle or Miss Creakle -LRB- who were both there , in the parlour -RRB- , or anything but Mr. Creakle , a stout gentleman with a bunch of watch-chain and seals , in an arm-chair , with a tumbler and bottle beside him .
Parsing [sent. 1773 len. 4]: ` So ! '
Parsing [sent. 1774 len. 4]: said Mr. Creakle .
Parsing [sent. 1775 len. 13]: ` This is the young gentleman whose teeth are to be filed !
Parsing [sent. 1776 len. 5]: Turn him round . '
Parsing [sent. 1777 len. 45]: The wooden-legged man turned me about so as to exhibit the placard ; and having afforded time for a full survey of it , turned me about again , with my face to Mr. Creakle , and posted himself at Mr. Creakle 's side .
Parsing [sent. 1778 len. 36]: Mr. Creakle 's face was fiery , and his eyes were small , and deep in his head ; he had thick veins in his forehead , a little nose , and a large chin .
Parsing [sent. 1779 len. 37]: He was bald on the top of his head ; and had some thin wet-looking hair that was just turning grey , brushed across each temple , so that the two sides interlaced on his forehead .
Parsing [sent. 1780 len. 24]: But the circumstance about him which impressed me most , was , that he had no voice , but spoke in a whisper .
Parsing [sent. 1781 len. 57]: The exertion this cost him , or the consciousness of talking in that feeble way , made his angry face so much more angry , and his thick veins so much thicker , when he spoke , that I am not surprised , on looking back , at this peculiarity striking me as his chief one .
Parsing [sent. 1782 len. 8]: ` Now , ' said Mr. Creakle .

Parsing [sent. 1784 len. 17]: ` There 's nothing against him yet , ' returned the man with the wooden leg .
Parsing [sent. 1785 len. 8]: ` There has been no opportunity . '
Parsing [sent. 1786 len. 7]: I thought Mr. Creakle was disappointed .

Parsing [sent. 1794 len. 5]: Do YOU know me ?

Parsing [sent. 1804 len. 3]: Hey ? '

Parsing [sent. 1806 len. 22]: I afterwards found that he generally acted , with his strong voice , as Mr. Creakle 's interpreter to the boys .
Parsing [sent. 1807 len. 17]: I was very much frightened , and said , I hoped so , if he pleased .
Parsing [sent. 1808 len. 20]: I felt , all this while , as if my ear were blazing ; he pinched it so hard .
Parsing [sent. 1809 len. 33]: ` I 'll tell you what I am , ' whispered Mr. Creakle , letting it go at last , with a screw at parting that brought the water into my eyes .
Parsing [sent. 1810 len. 8]: ` I 'm a Tartar . ' '
Parsing [sent. 1811 len. 12]: A Tartar , ' said the man with the wooden leg .
Parsing [sent. 1812 len. 39]: ` When I say I 'll do a thing , I do it , ' said Mr. Creakle ; ` and when I say I will have a thing done , I will have it done . ' '

Parsing [sent. 1814 len. 11]: I am a determined character , ' said Mr. Creakle .

Parsing [sent. 1817 len. 6]: That 's what I do .

Parsing [sent. 1821 len. 8]: ` No , ' was the answer .

Parsing [sent. 1824 len. 4]: He knows me .

Parsing [sent. 1827 len. 18]: Now you have begun to know me too , my young friend , and you may go .
Parsing [sent. 1828 len. 5]: Take him away . '
Parsing [sent. 1829 len. 33]: I was very glad to be ordered away , for Mrs. and Miss Creakle were both wiping their eyes , and I felt as uncomfortable for them as I did for myself .
Parsing [sent. 1830 len. 44]: But I had a petition on my mind which concerned me so nearly , that I could n't help saying , though I wondered at my own courage : ` If you please , sir -- ' Mr. Creakle whispered , ` Hah !
Parsing [sent. 1831 len. 5]: What 's this ? '
Parsing [sent. 1832 len. 18]: and bent his eyes upon me , as if he would have burnt me up with them .
Parsing [sent. 1833 len. 134]: ` If you please , sir , ' I faltered , ` if I might be allowed -LRB- I am very sorry indeed , sir , for what I did -RRB- to take this writing off , before the boys come back -- ' Whether Mr. Creakle was in earnest , or whether he only did it to frighten me , I do n't know , but he made a burst out of his chair , before which I precipitately retreated , without waiting for the escort Of the man with the wooden leg , and never once stopped until I reached my own bedroom , where , finding I was not pursued , I went to bed , as it was time , and lay quaking , for a couple of hours .
Parsing [sent. 1834 len. 7]: Next morning Mr. Sharp came back .
Parsing [sent. 1835 len. 13]: Mr. Sharp was the first master , and superior to Mr. Mell .
Parsing [sent. 1836 len. 21]: Mr. Mell took his meals with the boys , but Mr. Sharp dined and supped at Mr. Creakle 's table .
Parsing [sent. 1837 len. 40]: He was a limp , delicate-looking gentleman , I thought , with a good deal of nose , and a way of carrying his head on one side , as if it were a little too heavy for him .
Parsing [sent. 1838 len. 47]: His hair was very smooth and wavy ; but I was informed by the very first boy who came back that it was a wig -LRB- a second-hand one HE said -RRB- , and that Mr. Sharp went out every Saturday afternoon to get it curled .
Parsing [sent. 1839 len. 15]: It was no other than Tommy Traddles who gave me this piece of intelligence .
Parsing [sent. 1840 len. 8]: He was the first boy who returned .
Parsing [sent. 1841 len. 35]: He introduced himself by informing me that I should find his name on the right - hand corner of the gate , over the top-bolt ; upon that I said , ` Traddles ? '
Parsing [sent. 1842 len. 24]: to which he replied , ` The same , ' and then he asked me for a full account of myself and family .
Parsing [sent. 1843 len. 13]: It was a happy circumstance for me that Traddles came back first .
Parsing [sent. 1844 len. 50]: He enjoyed my placard so much , that he saved me from the embarrassment of either disclosure or concealment , by presenting me to every other boy who came back , great or small , immediately on his arrival , in this form of introduction , ` Look here !
Parsing [sent. 1845 len. 6]: Here 's a game ! '
Parsing [sent. 1846 len. 27]: Happily , too , the greater part of the boys came back low-spirited , and were not so boisterous at my expense as I had expected .
Parsing [sent. 1847 len. 50]: Some of them certainly did dance about me like wild Indians , and the greater part could not resist the temptation of pretending that I was a dog , and patting and soothing me , lest I should bite , and saying , ` Lie down , sir ! '
Parsing [sent. 1848 len. 5]: and calling me Towzer .
Parsing [sent. 1849 len. 29]: This was naturally confusing , among so many strangers , and cost me some tears , but on the whole it was much better than I had anticipated .
Parsing [sent. 1850 len. 19]: I was not considered as being formally received into the school , however , until J. Steerforth arrived .
Parsing [sent. 1851 len. 34]: Before this boy , who was reputed to be a great scholar , and was very good-looking , and at least half-a-dozen years my senior , I was carried as before a magistrate .
Parsing [sent. 1852 len. 43]: He inquired , under a shed in the playground , into the particulars of my punishment , and was pleased to express his opinion that it was ' a jolly shame ' ; for which I became bound to him ever afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 1853 len. 10]: ` What money have you got , Copperfield ? '
Parsing [sent. 1854 len. 18]: he said , walking aside with me when he had disposed of my affair in these terms .
Parsing [sent. 1855 len. 6]: I told him seven shillings .
Parsing [sent. 1856 len. 17]: ` You had better give it to me to take care of , ' he said .
Parsing [sent. 1857 len. 10]: ` At least , you can if you like .
Parsing [sent. 1858 len. 10]: You need n't if you do n't like . '
Parsing [sent. 1859 len. 23]: I hastened to comply with his friendly suggestion , and opening Peggotty 's purse , turned it upside down into his hand .
Parsing [sent. 1860 len. 10]: ` Do you want to spend anything now ? '
Parsing [sent. 1861 len. 4]: he asked me .
Parsing [sent. 1862 len. 9]: ` No thank you , ' I replied .
Parsing [sent. 1863 len. 15]: ` You can , if you like , you know , ' said Steerforth .
Parsing [sent. 1864 len. 6]: ` Say the word . '
Parsing [sent. 1865 len. 12]: ` No , thank you , sir , ' I repeated .
Parsing [sent. 1866 len. 30]: ` Perhaps you 'd like to spend a couple of shillings or so , in a bottle of currant wine by and by , up in the bedroom ? '
Parsing [sent. 1867 len. 3]: said Steerforth .
Parsing [sent. 1868 len. 11]: ` You belong to my bedroom , I find . '
Parsing [sent. 1869 len. 20]: It certainly had not occurred to me before , but I said , Yes , I should like that .
Parsing [sent. 1870 len. 8]: ` Very good , ' said Steerforth .
Parsing [sent. 1871 len. 21]: ` You 'll be glad to spend another shilling or so , in almond cakes , I dare say ? '
Parsing [sent. 1872 len. 12]: I said , Yes , I should like that , too .
Parsing [sent. 1873 len. 17]: ` And another shilling or so in biscuits , and another in fruit , eh ? '
Parsing [sent. 1874 len. 4]: said Steerforth . '
Parsing [sent. 1875 len. 12]: I say , young Copperfield , you 're going it ! '
Parsing [sent. 1876 len. 18]: I smiled because he smiled , but I was a little troubled in my mind , too .
Parsing [sent. 1877 len. 4]: ` Well ! '
Parsing [sent. 1878 len. 3]: said Steerforth .
Parsing [sent. 1879 len. 16]: ` We must make it stretch as far as we can ; that 's all .
Parsing [sent. 1880 len. 11]: I 'll do the best in my power for you .
Parsing [sent. 1881 len. 17]: I can go out when I like , and I 'll smuggle the prog in . '
Parsing [sent. 1882 len. 31]: With these words he put the money in his pocket , and kindly told me not to make myself uneasy ; he would take care it should be all right .
Parsing [sent. 1883 len. 57]: He was as good as his word , if that were all right which I had a secret misgiving was nearly all wrong -- for I feared it was a waste of my mother 's two half-crowns -- though I had preserved the piece of paper they were wrapped in : which was a precious saving .
Parsing [sent. 1884 len. 46]: When we went upstairs to bed , he produced the whole seven shillings ` worth , and laid it out on my bed in the moonlight , saying : ` There you are , young Copperfield , and a royal spread you 've got . '
Parsing [sent. 1885 len. 33]: I could n't think of doing the honours of the feast , at my time of life , while he was by ; my hand shook at the very thought of it .
Parsing [sent. 1886 len. 69]: I begged him to do me the favour of presiding ; and my request being seconded by the other boys who were in that room , he acceded to it , and sat upon my pillow , handing round the viands -- with perfect fairness , I must say -- and dispensing the currant wine in a little glass without a foot , which was his own property .
Parsing [sent. 1887 len. 28]: As to me , I sat on his left hand , and the rest were grouped about us , on the nearest beds and on the floor .
Parsing [sent. 1888 len. 91]: How well I recollect our sitting there , talking in whispers ; or their talking , and my respectfully listening , I ought rather to say ; the moonlight falling a little way into the room , through the window , painting a pale window on the floor , and the greater part of us in shadow , except when Steerforth dipped a match into a phosphorus-box , when he wanted to look for anything on the board , and shed a blue glare over us that was gone directly !
Parsing [sent. 1889 len. 79]: A certain mysterious feeling , consequent on the darkness , the secrecy of the revel , and the whisper in which everything was said , steals over me again , and I listen to all they tell me with a vague feeling of solemnity and awe , which makes me glad that they are all so near , and frightens me -LRB- though I feign to laugh -RRB- when Traddles pretends to see a ghost in the corner .
Parsing [sent. 1890 len. 15]: I heard all kinds of things about the school and all belonging to it .
Parsing [sent. 1891 len. 59]: I heard that Mr. Creakle had not preferred his claim to being a Tartar without reason ; that he was the sternest and most severe of masters ; that he laid about him , right and left , every day of his life , charging in among the boys like a trooper , and slashing away , unmercifully .
Parsing [sent. 1892 len. 68]: That he knew nothing himself , but the art of slashing , being more ignorant -LRB- J. Steerforth said -RRB- than the lowest boy in the school ; that he had been , a good many years ago , a small hop-dealer in the Borough , and had taken to the schooling business after being bankrupt in hops , and making away with Mrs. Creakle 's money .
Parsing [sent. 1893 len. 16]: With a good deal more of that sort , which I wondered how they knew .
Parsing [sent. 1894 len. 77]: I heard that the man with the wooden leg , whose name was Tungay , was an obstinate barbarian who had formerly assisted in the hop business , but had come into the scholastic line with Mr. Creakle , in consequence , as was supposed among the boys , of his having broken his leg in Mr. Creakle 's service , and having done a deal of dishonest work for him , and knowing his secrets .
Parsing [sent. 1895 len. 41]: I heard that with the single exception of Mr. Creakle , Tungay considered the whole establishment , masters and boys , as his natural enemies , and that the only delight of his life was to be sour and malicious .
Parsing [sent. 1896 len. 62]: I heard that Mr. Creakle had a son , who had not been Tungay 's friend , and who , assisting in the school , had once held some remonstrance with his father on an occasion when its discipline was very cruelly exercised , and was supposed , besides , to have protested against his father 's usage of his mother .
Parsing [sent. 1897 len. 31]: I heard that Mr. Creakle had turned him out of doors , in consequence ; and that Mrs. and Miss Creakle had been in a sad way , ever since .
Parsing [sent. 1898 len. 36]: But the greatest wonder that I heard of Mr. Creakle was , there being one boy in the school on whom he never ventured to lay a hand , and that boy being J. Steerforth .
Parsing [sent. 1899 len. 23]: Steerforth himself confirmed this when it was stated , and said that he should like to begin to see him do it .
Parsing [sent. 1900 len. 68]: On being asked by a mild boy -LRB- not me -RRB- how he would proceed if he did begin to see him do it , he dipped a match into his phosphorus-box on purpose to shed a glare over his reply , and said he would commence by knocking him down with a blow on the forehead from the seven-and-sixpenny ink-bottle that was always on the mantelpiece .
Parsing [sent. 1901 len. 11]: We sat in the dark for some time , breathless .
Parsing [sent. 1902 len. 56]: I heard that Mr. Sharp and Mr. Mell were both supposed to be wretchedly paid ; and that when there was hot and cold meat for dinner at Mr. Creakle 's table , Mr. Sharp was always expected to say he preferred cold ; which was again corroborated by J. Steerforth , the only parlour-boarder .
Parsing [sent. 1903 len. 46]: I heard that Mr. Sharp 's wig did n't fit him ; and that he need n't be so ` bounceable ' -- somebody else said ` bumptious ' -- about it , because his own red hair was very plainly to be seen behind .
Parsing [sent. 1904 len. 47]: I heard that one boy , who was a coal-merchant 's son , came as a set-off against the coal-bill , and was called , on that account , ` Exchange or Barter ' -- a name selected from the arithmetic book as expressing this arrangement .
Parsing [sent. 1905 len. 18]: I heard that the table beer was a robbery of parents , and the pudding an imposition .
Parsing [sent. 1906 len. 58]: I heard that Miss Creakle was regarded by the school in general as being in love with Steerforth ; and I am sure , as I sat in the dark , thinking of his nice voice , and his fine face , and his easy manner , and his curling hair , I thought it very likely .
Parsing [sent. 1907 len. 43]: I heard that Mr. Mell was not a bad sort of fellow , but had n't a sixpence to bless himself with ; and that there was no doubt that old Mrs. Mell , his mother , was as poor as job .

Parsing [sent. 2285 len. 137]: The rest of the half-year is a jumble in my recollection of the daily strife and struggle of our lives ; of the waning summer and the changing season ; of the frosty mornings when we were rung out of bed , and the cold , cold smell of the dark nights when we were rung into bed again ; of the evening schoolroom dimly lighted and indifferently warmed , and the morning schoolroom which was nothing but a great shivering-machine ; of the alternation of boiled beef with roast beef , and boiled mutton with roast mutton ; of clods of bread-and-butter , dog 's - eared lesson-books , cracked slates , tear-blotted copy-books , canings , rulerings , hair-cuttings , rainy Sundays , suet-puddings , and a dirty atmosphere of ink , surrounding all .

Parsing [sent. 3196 len. 68]: Peggotty was dressed as usual , in her neat and quiet mourning ; but Mr. Barkis bloomed in a new blue coat , of which the tailor had given him such good measure , that the cuffs would have rendered gloves unnecessary in the coldest weather , while the collar was so high that it pushed his hair up on end on the top of his head .

Parsing [sent. 3211 len. 16]: Which I really thought was a sensible idea , that Ham might have acted on .

Parsing [sent. 3355 len. 63]: Chapter 11 I Begin Life on My Own Account , and Do n't Like it I know enough of the world now , to have almost lost the capacity of being much surprised by anything ; but it is matter of some surprise to me , even now , that I can have been so easily thrown away at such an age .
Parsing [sent. 3356 len. 42]: A child of excellent abilities , and with strong powers of observation , quick , eager , delicate , and soon hurt bodily or mentally , it seems wonderful to me that nobody should have made any sign in my behalf .
Parsing [sent. 3357 len. 26]: But none was made ; and I became , at ten years old , a little labouring hind in the service of Murdstone and Grinby .
Parsing [sent. 3358 len. 10]: Murdstone and Grinby 's warehouse was at the waterside .
Parsing [sent. 3359 len. 6]: It was down in Blackfriars .
Parsing [sent. 3360 len. 40]: Modern improvements have altered the place ; but it was the last house at the bottom of a narrow street , curving down hill to the river , with some stairs at the end , where people took boat .
Parsing [sent. 3361 len. 39]: It was a crazy old house with a wharf of its own , abutting on the water when the tide was in , and on the mud when the tide was out , and literally overrun with rats .
Parsing [sent. 3362 len. 67]: Its panelled rooms , discoloured with the dirt and smoke of a hundred years , I dare say ; its decaying floors and staircase ; the squeaking and scuffling of the old grey rats down in the cellars ; and the dirt and rottenness of the place ; are things , not of many years ago , in my mind , but of the present instant .
Parsing [sent. 3363 len. 33]: They are all before me , just as they were in the evil hour when I went among them for the first time , with my trembling hand in Mr. Quinion 's .
Parsing [sent. 3364 len. 32]: Murdstone and Grinby 's trade was among a good many kinds of people , but an important branch of it was the supply of wines and spirits to certain packet ships .
Parsing [sent. 3365 len. 27]: I forget now where they chiefly went , but I think there were some among them that made voyages both to the East and West Indies .
Parsing [sent. 3366 len. 46]: I know that a great many empty bottles were one of the consequences of this traffic , and that certain men and boys were employed to examine them against the light , and reject those that were flawed , and to rinse and wash them .
Parsing [sent. 3367 len. 43]: When the empty bottles ran short , there were labels to be pasted on full ones , or corks to be fitted to them , or seals to be put upon the corks , or finished bottles to be packed in casks .
Parsing [sent. 3368 len. 18]: All this work was my work , and of the boys employed upon it I was one .
Parsing [sent. 3369 len. 11]: There were three or four of us , counting me .
Parsing [sent. 3370 len. 47]: My working place was established in a corner of the warehouse , where Mr. Quinion could see me , when he chose to stand up on the bottom rail of his stool in the counting-house , and look at me through a window above the desk .
Parsing [sent. 3371 len. 31]: Hither , on the first morning of my so auspiciously beginning life on my own account , the oldest of the regular boys was summoned to show me my business .
Parsing [sent. 3372 len. 17]: His name was Mick Walker , and he wore a ragged apron and a paper cap .
Parsing [sent. 3373 len. 26]: He informed me that his father was a bargeman , and walked , in a black velvet head-dress , in the Lord Mayor 's Show .
Parsing [sent. 3374 len. 27]: He also informed me that our principal associate would be another boy whom he introduced by the -- to me -- extraordinary name of Mealy Potatoes .
Parsing [sent. 3375 len. 40]: I discovered , however , that this youth had not been christened by that name , but that it had been bestowed upon him in the warehouse , on account of his complexion , which was pale or mealy .
Parsing [sent. 3376 len. 49]: Mealy 's father was a waterman , who had the additional distinction of being a fireman , and was engaged as such at one of the large theatres ; where some young relation of Mealy 's -- I think his little sister -- did Imps in the Pantomimes .
Parsing [sent. 3377 len. 64]: No words can express the secret agony of my soul as I sunk into this companionship ; compared these henceforth everyday associates with those of my happier childhood -- not to say with Steerforth , Traddles , and the rest of those boys ; and felt my hopes of growing up to be a learned and distinguished man , crushed in my bosom .
Parsing [sent. 3378 len. 85]: The deep remembrance of the sense I had , of being utterly without hope now ; of the shame I felt in my position ; of the misery it was to my young heart to believe that day by day what I had learned , and thought , and delighted in , and raised my fancy and my emulation up by , would pass away from me , little by little , never to be brought back any more ; can not be written .
Parsing [sent. 3379 len. 50]: As often as Mick Walker went away in the course of that forenoon , I mingled my tears with the water in which I was washing the bottles ; and sobbed as if there were a flaw in my own breast , and it were in danger of bursting .

Parsing [sent. 3449 len. 15]: In this house , and with this family , I passed my leisure time .

Parsing [sent. 3452 len. 37]: This made a hole in the six or seven shillings , I know well ; and I was out at the warehouse all day , and had to support myself on that money all the week .
Parsing [sent. 3453 len. 49]: From Monday morning until Saturday night , I had no advice , no counsel , no encouragement , no consolation , no assistance , no support , of any kind , from anyone , that I can call to mind , as I hope to go to heaven !
Parsing [sent. 3454 len. 18]: I was so young and childish , and so little qualified -- how could I be otherwise ?
Parsing [sent. 3455 len. 59]: -- to undertake the whole charge of my own existence , that often , in going to Murdstone and Grinby 's , of a morning , I could not resist the stale pastry put out for sale at half-price at the pastrycooks ' doors , and spent in that the money I should have kept for my dinner .
Parsing [sent. 3456 len. 18]: Then , I went without my dinner , or bought a roll or a slice of pudding .
Parsing [sent. 3457 len. 17]: I remember two pudding shops , between which I was divided , according to my finances .

Parsing [sent. 3504 len. 15]: Mr. Micawber 's difficulties were an addition to the distressed state of my mind .
Parsing [sent. 3505 len. 40]: In my forlorn state I became quite attached to the family , and used to walk about , busy with Mrs. Micawber 's calculations of ways and means , and heavy with the weight of Mr. Micawber 's debts .
Parsing [sent. 3506 len. 96]: On a Saturday night , which was my grand treat , - partly because it was a great thing to walk home with six or seven shillings in my pocket , looking into the shops and thinking what such a sum would buy , and partly because I went home early , -- Mrs. Micawber would make the most heart-rending confidences to me ; also on a Sunday morning , when I mixed the portion of tea or coffee I had bought over-night , in a little shaving-pot , and sat late at my breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 3507 len. 40]: It was nothing at all unusual for Mr. Micawber to sob violently at the beginning of one of these Saturday night conversations , and sing about jack 's delight being his lovely Nan , towards the end of it .
Parsing [sent. 3508 len. 57]: I have known him come home to supper with a flood of tears , and a declaration that nothing was now left but a jail ; and go to bed making a calculation of the expense of putting bow-windows to the house , ` in case anything turned up ' , which was his favourite expression .
Parsing [sent. 3509 len. 8]: And Mrs. Micawber was just the same .

Parsing [sent. 3531 len. 22]: Mr. Micawber had a few books on a little chiffonier , which he called the library ; and those went first .
Parsing [sent. 3532 len. 43]: I carried them , one after another , to a bookstall in the City Road -- one part of which , near our house , was almost all bookstalls and bird shops then -- and sold them for whatever they would bring .
Parsing [sent. 3533 len. 33]: The keeper of this bookstall , who lived in a little house behind it , used to get tipsy every night , and to be violently scolded by his wife every morning .
Parsing [sent. 3534 len. 103]: More than once , when I went there early , I had audience of him in a turn-up bedstead , with a cut in his forehead or a black eye , bearing witness to his excesses over-night -LRB- I am afraid he was quarrelsome in his drink -RRB- , and he , with a shaking hand , endeavouring to find the needful shillings in one or other of the pockets of his clothes , which lay upon the floor , while his wife , with a baby in her arms and her shoes down at heel , never left off rating him .
Parsing [sent. 3535 len. 53]: Sometimes he had lost his money , and then he would ask me to call again ; but his wife had always got some -- had taken his , I dare say , while he was drunk -- and secretly completed the bargain on the stairs , as we went down together .
Parsing [sent. 3536 len. 16]: At the pawnbroker 's shop , too , I began to be very well known .
Parsing [sent. 3537 len. 51]: The principal gentleman who officiated behind the counter , took a good deal of notice of me ; and often got me , I recollect , to decline a Latin noun or adjective , or to conjugate a Latin verb , in his ear , while he transacted my business .
Parsing [sent. 3538 len. 31]: After all these occasions Mrs. Micawber made a little treat , which was generally a supper ; and there was a peculiar relish in these meals which I well remember .

Parsing [sent. 3724 len. 67]: Again , and again , and a hundred times again , since the night when the thought had first occurred to me and banished sleep , I had gone over that old story of my poor mother 's about my birth , which it had been one of my great delights in the old time to hear her tell , and which I knew by heart .
Parsing [sent. 3725 len. 45]: My aunt walked into that story , and walked out of it , a dread and awful personage ; but there was one little trait in her behaviour which I liked to dwell on , and which gave me some faint shadow of encouragement .
Parsing [sent. 3726 len. 79]: I could not forget how my mother had thought that she felt her touch her pretty hair with no ungentle hand ; and though it might have been altogether my mother 's fancy , and might have had no foundation whatever in fact , I made a little picture , out of it , of my terrible aunt relenting towards the girlish beauty that I recollected so well and loved so much , which softened the whole narrative .
Parsing [sent. 3727 len. 22]: It is very possible that it had been in my mind a long time , and had gradually engendered my determination .
Parsing [sent. 3728 len. 60]: As I did not even know where Miss Betsey lived , I wrote a long letter to Peggotty , and asked her , incidentally , if she remembered ; pretending that I had heard of such a lady living at a certain place I named at random , and had a curiosity to know if it were the same .
Parsing [sent. 3729 len. 57]: In the course of that letter , I told Peggotty that I had a particular occasion for half a guinea ; and that if she could lend me that sum until I could repay it , I should be very much obliged to her , and would tell her afterwards what I had wanted it for .

Parsing [sent. 3732 len. 44]: One of our men , however , informing me on my asking him about these places , that they were all close together , I deemed this enough for my object , and resolved to set out at the end of that week .
Parsing [sent. 3733 len. 72]: Being a very honest little creature , and unwilling to disgrace the memory I was going to leave behind me at Murdstone and Grinby 's , I considered myself bound to remain until Saturday night ; and , as I had been paid a week 's wages in advance when I first came there , not to present myself in the counting-house at the usual hour , to receive my stipend .
Parsing [sent. 3734 len. 23]: For this express reason , I had borrowed the half-guinea , that I might not be without a fund for my travelling-expenses .
Parsing [sent. 3735 len. 90]: Accordingly , when the Saturday night came , and we were all waiting in the warehouse to be paid , and Tipp the carman , who always took precedence , went in first to draw his money , I shook Mick Walker by the hand ; asked him , when it came to his turn to be paid , to say to Mr. Quinion that I had gone to move my box to Tipp 's ; and , bidding a last good night to Mealy Potatoes , ran away .
Parsing [sent. 3736 len. 55]: My box was at my old lodging , over the water , and I had written a direction for it on the back of one of our address cards that we nailed on the casks : ` Master David , to be left till called for , at the Coach Office , Dover . '
Parsing [sent. 3737 len. 49]: This I had in my pocket ready to put on the box , after I should have got it out of the house ; and as I went towards my lodging , I looked about me for someone who would help me to carry it to the booking-office .

Parsing [sent. 3768 len. 105]: At length , confused by fright and heat , and doubting whether half London might not by this time be turning out for my apprehension , I left the young man to go where he would with my box and money ; and , panting and crying , but never stopping , faced about for Greenwich , which I had understood was on the Dover Road : taking very little more out of the world , towards the retreat of my aunt , Miss Betsey , than I had brought into it , on the night when my arrival gave her so much umbrage .

Parsing [sent. 3801 len. 20]: A plan had occurred to me for passing the night , which I was going to carry into execution .

Parsing [sent. 3803 len. 49]: I imagined it would be a kind of company to have the boys , and the bedroom where I used to tell the stories , so near me : although the boys would know nothing of my being there , and the bedroom would yield me no shelter .
Parsing [sent. 3804 len. 29]: I had had a hard day 's work , and was pretty well jaded when I came climbing out , at last , upon the level of Blackheath .
Parsing [sent. 3805 len. 56]: It cost me some trouble to find out Salem House ; but I found it , and I found a haystack in the corner , and I lay down by it ; having first walked round the wall , and looked up at the windows , and seen that all was dark and silent within .
Parsing [sent. 3806 len. 19]: Never shall I forget the lonely sensation of first lying down , without a roof above my head !
Parsing [sent. 3807 len. 70]: Sleep came upon me as it came on many other outcasts , against whom house-doors were locked , and house-dogs barked , that night -- and I dreamed of lying on my old school-bed , talking to the boys in my room ; and found myself sitting upright , with Steerforth 's name upon my lips , looking wildly at the stars that were glistening and glimmering above me .
Parsing [sent. 3808 len. 34]: When I remembered where I was at that untimely hour , a feeling stole upon me that made me get up , afraid of I do n't know what , and walk about .

Parsing [sent. 3810 len. 31]: If I could have hoped that Steerforth was there , I would have lurked about until he came out alone ; but I knew he must have left long since .

Parsing [sent. 3812 len. 61]: So I crept away from the wall as Mr. Creakle 's boys were getting up , and struck into the long dusty track which I had first known to be the Dover Road when I was one of them , and when I little expected that any eyes would ever see me the wayfarer I was now , upon it .
Parsing [sent. 3813 len. 13]: What a different Sunday morning from the old Sunday morning at Yarmouth !
Parsing [sent. 3814 len. 81]: In due time I heard the church-bells ringing , as I plodded on ; and I met people who were going to church ; and I passed a church or two where the congregation were inside , and the sound of singing came out into the sunshine , while the beadle sat and cooled himself in the shade of the porch , or stood beneath the yew-tree , with his hand to his forehead , glowering at me going by .

Parsing [sent. 3827 len. 34]: Accordingly , I took the jacket off , that I might learn to do without it ; and carrying it under my arm , began a tour of inspection of the various slop-shops .

Parsing [sent. 4525 len. 10]: I never thought of anything about myself , distinctly .
Parsing [sent. 4526 len. 49]: The two things clearest in my mind were , that a remoteness had come upon the old Blunderstone life -- which seemed to lie in the haze of an immeasurable distance ; and that a curtain had for ever fallen on my life at Murdstone and Grinby 's .
Parsing [sent. 4527 len. 9]: No one has ever raised that curtain since .
Parsing [sent. 4528 len. 23]: I have lifted it for a moment , even in this narrative , with a reluctant hand , and dropped it gladly .
Parsing [sent. 4529 len. 43]: The remembrance of that life is fraught with so much pain to me , with so much mental suffering and want of hope , that I have never had the courage even to examine how long I was doomed to lead it .
Parsing [sent. 4530 len. 18]: Whether it lasted for a year , or more , or less , I do not know .
Parsing [sent. 4531 len. 24]: I only know that it was , and ceased to be ; and that I have written , and there I leave it .
Parsing [sent. 4532 len. 38]: Chapter 15 I Make Another Beginning Mr. Dick and I soon became the best of friends , and very often , when his day 's work was done , went out together to fly the great kite .
Parsing [sent. 4533 len. 52]: Every day of his life he had a long sitting at the Memorial , which never made the least progress , however hard he laboured , for King Charles the First always strayed into it , sooner or later , and then it was thrown aside , and another one begun .
Parsing [sent. 4534 len. 63]: The patience and hope with which he bore these perpetual disappointments , the mild perception he had that there was something wrong about King Charles the First , the feeble efforts he made to keep him out , and the certainty with which he came in , and tumbled the Memorial out of all shape , made a deep impression on me .
Parsing [sent. 4535 len. 43]: What Mr. Dick supposed would come of the Memorial , if it were completed ; where he thought it was to go , or what he thought it was to do ; he knew no more than anybody else , I believe .
Parsing [sent. 4536 len. 35]: Nor was it at all necessary that he should trouble himself with such questions , for if anything were certain under the sun , it was certain that the Memorial never would be finished .
Parsing [sent. 4537 len. 29]: It was quite an affecting sight , I used to think , to see him with the kite when it was up a great height in the air .
Parsing [sent. 4538 len. 67]: What he had told me , in his room , about his belief in its disseminating the statements pasted on it , which were nothing but old leaves of abortive Memorials , might have been a fancy with him sometimes ; but not when he was out , looking up at the kite in the sky , and feeling it pull and tug at his hand .
Parsing [sent. 4539 len. 10]: He never looked so serene as he did then .
Parsing [sent. 4540 len. 55]: I used to fancy , as I sat by him of an evening , on a green slope , and saw him watch the kite high in the quiet air , that it lifted his mind out of its confusion , and bore it -LRB- such was my boyish thought -RRB- into the skies .
Parsing [sent. 4541 len. 83]: As he wound the string in and it came lower and lower down out of the beautiful light , until it fluttered to the ground , and lay there like a dead thing , he seemed to wake gradually out of a dream ; and I remember to have seen him take it up , and look about him in a lost way , as if they had both come down together , so that I pitied him with all my heart .
Parsing [sent. 4542 len. 27]: While I advanced in friendship and intimacy with Mr. Dick , I did not go backward in the favour of his staunch friend , my aunt .
Parsing [sent. 4543 len. 58]: She took so kindly to me , that , in the course of a few weeks , she shortened my adopted name of Trotwood into Trot ; and even encouraged me to hope , that if I went on as I had begun , I might take equal rank in her affections with my sister Betsey Trotwood .
Parsing [sent. 4544 len. 32]: ` Trot , ' said my aunt one evening , when the backgammon-board was placed as usual for herself and Mr. Dick , ` we must not forget your education . '
Parsing [sent. 4545 len. 19]: This was my only subject of anxiety , and I felt quite delighted by her referring to it .
Parsing [sent. 4546 len. 12]: ` Should you like to go to school at Canterbury ? '
Parsing [sent. 4547 len. 4]: said my aunt .
Parsing [sent. 4548 len. 17]: I replied that I should like it very much , as it was so near her .
Parsing [sent. 4549 len. 8]: ` Good , ' said my aunt .
Parsing [sent. 4550 len. 9]: ` Should you like to go tomorrow ? '

Parsing [sent. 4554 len. 75]: I was greatly elated by these orders ; but my heart smote me for my selfishness , when I witnessed their effect on Mr. Dick , who was so low-spirited at the prospect of our separation , and played so ill in consequence , that my aunt , after giving him several admonitory raps on the knuckles with her dice-box , shut up the board , and declined to play with him any more .
Parsing [sent. 4555 len. 51]: But , on hearing from my aunt that I should sometimes come over on a Saturday , and that he could sometimes come and see me on a Wednesday , he revived ; and vowed to make another kite for those occasions , of proportions greatly surpassing the present one .

Parsing [sent. 4557 len. 32]: We parted at the garden-gate in a most affectionate manner , and Mr. Dick did not go into the house until my aunt had driven me out of sight of it .
Parsing [sent. 4558 len. 57]: My aunt , who was perfectly indifferent to public opinion , drove the grey pony through Dover in a masterly manner ; sitting high and stiff like a state coachman , keeping a steady eye upon him wherever he went , and making a point of not letting him have his own way in any respect .
Parsing [sent. 4559 len. 39]: When we came into the country road , she permitted him to relax a little , however ; and looking at me down in a valley of cushion by her side , asked me whether I was happy ?

Parsing [sent. 4572 len. 61]: At length we stopped before a very old house bulging out over the road ; a house with long low lattice-windows bulging out still farther , and beams with carved heads on the ends bulging out too , so that I fancied the whole house was leaning forward , trying to see who was passing on the narrow pavement below .
Parsing [sent. 4573 len. 8]: It was quite spotless in its cleanliness .
Parsing [sent. 4574 len. 89]: The old-fashioned brass knocker on the low arched door , ornamented with carved garlands of fruit and flowers , twinkled like a star ; the two stone steps descending to the door were as white as if they had been covered with fair linen ; and all the angles and corners , and carvings and mouldings , and quaint little panes of glass , and quainter little windows , though as old as the hills , were as pure as any snow that ever fell upon the hills .

Parsing [sent. 4714 len. 25]: Chapter 16 I Am a New Boy in More Senses than One Next morning , after breakfast , I entered on school life again .
