Parsing [sent. 6242 len. 45]: Chapter 21 Little Em ` ly There was a servant in that house , a man who , I understood , was usually with Steerforth , and had come into his service at the University , who was in appearance a pattern of respectability .
Parsing [sent. 6243 len. 13]: I believe there never existed in his station a more respectable-looking man .
Parsing [sent. 6244 len. 39]: He was taciturn , soft-footed , very quiet in his manner , deferential , observant , always at hand when wanted , and never near when not wanted ; but his great claim to consideration was his respectability .
Parsing [sent. 6245 len. 69]: He had not a pliant face , he had rather a stiff neck , rather a tight smooth head with short hair clinging to it at the sides , a soft way of speaking , with a peculiar habit of whispering the letter S so distinctly , that he seemed to use it oftener than any other man ; but every peculiarity that he had he made respectable .
Parsing [sent. 6246 len. 14]: If his nose had been upside-down , he would have made that respectable .
Parsing [sent. 6247 len. 15]: He surrounded himself with an atmosphere of respectability , and walked secure in it .
Parsing [sent. 6248 len. 20]: It would have been next to impossible to suspect him of anything wrong , he was so thoroughly respectable .
Parsing [sent. 6249 len. 17]: Nobody could have thought of putting him in a livery , he was so highly respectable .
Parsing [sent. 6250 len. 26]: To have imposed any derogatory work upon him , would have been to inflict a wanton insult on the feelings of a most respectable man .
Parsing [sent. 6251 len. 37]: And of this , I noticed - the women-servants in the household were so intuitively conscious , that they always did such work themselves , and generally while he read the paper by the pantry fire .
Parsing [sent. 6252 len. 8]: Such a self-contained man I never saw .
Parsing [sent. 6253 len. 21]: But in that quality , as in every other he possessed , he only seemed to be the more respectable .

Parsing [sent. 7377 len. 63]: It 's a little out-of-the-way place , where they administer what is called ecclesiastical law , and play all kinds of tricks with obsolete old monsters of acts of Parliament , which three-fourths of the world know nothing about , and the other fourth supposes to have been dug up , in a fossil state , in the days of the Edwards .

Parsing [sent. 8327 len. 5]: What was the Arches ?
Parsing [sent. 8328 len. 36]: The same court , in the same room , with the same bar , and the same practitioners , but another judge , for there the Consistory judge could plead any court-day as an advocate .
Parsing [sent. 8329 len. 10]: Well , you played your round game out again .
Parsing [sent. 8330 len. 6]: Still you were not satisfied .
Parsing [sent. 8331 len. 3]: Very good .
Parsing [sent. 8332 len. 6]: What did you do then ?
Parsing [sent. 8333 len. 8]: Why , you went to the Delegates .
Parsing [sent. 8334 len. 5]: Who were the Delegates ?
Parsing [sent. 8335 len. 69]: Why , the Ecclesiastical Delegates were the advocates without any business , who had looked on at the round game when it was playing in both courts , and had seen the cards shuffled , and cut , and played , and had talked to all the players about it , and now came fresh , as judges , to settle the matter to the satisfaction of everybody !
Parsing [sent. 8336 len. 81]: Discontented people might talk of corruption in the Commons , closeness in the Commons , and the necessity of reforming the Commons , said Mr. Spenlow solemnly , in conclusion ; but when the price of wheat per bushel had been highest , the Commons had been busiest ; and a man might lay his hand upon his heart , and say this to the whole world , -- ` Touch the Commons , and down comes the country ! '

Parsing [sent. 10343 len. 12]: I believe the theme of this incomprehensible conundrum was the moon .
Parsing [sent. 10344 len. 86]: No matter what it was , I , the moon-struck slave of Dora , perambulated round and round the house and garden for two hours , looking through crevices in the palings , getting my chin by dint of violent exertion above the rusty nails on the top , blowing kisses at the lights in the windows , and romantically calling on the night , at intervals , to shield my Dora -- I do n't exactly know what from , I suppose from fire .

Parsing [sent. 10443 len. 150]: I replied , with all due deference to his experience -LRB- but with more deference , I am afraid , to his being Dora 's father -RRB- , that perhaps it was a little nonsensical that the Registry of that Court , containing the original wills of all persons leaving effects within the immense province of Canterbury , for three whole centuries , should be an accidental building , never designed for the purpose , leased by the registrars for their Own private emolument , unsafe , not even ascertained to be fire-proof , choked with the important documents it held , and positively , from the roof to the basement , a mercenary speculation of the registrars , who took great fees from the public , and crammed the public 's wills away anyhow and anywhere , having no other object than to get rid of them cheaply .
Parsing [sent. 10444 len. 85]: That , perhaps , it was a little unreasonable that these registrars in the receipt of profits amounting to eight or nine thousand pounds a year -LRB- to say nothing of the profits of the deputy registrars , and clerks of seats -RRB- , should not be obliged to spend a little of that money , in finding a reasonably safe place for the important documents which all classes of people were compelled to hand over to them , whether they would or no .
Parsing [sent. 10445 len. 52]: That , perhaps , it was a little unjust , that all the great offices in this great office should be magnificent sinecures , while the unfortunate working-clerks in the cold dark room upstairs were the worst rewarded , and the least considered men , doing important services , in London .

Parsing [sent. 10447 len. 65]: That , perhaps , in short , this Prerogative Office of the diocese of Canterbury was altogether such a pestilent job , and such a pernicious absurdity , that but for its being squeezed away in a corner of St. Paul 's Churchyard , which few people knew , it must have been turned completely inside out , and upside down , long ago .

Parsing [sent. 11875 len. 44]: I bought an approved scheme of the noble art and mystery of stenography -LRB- which cost me ten and sixpence -RRB- ; and plunged into a sea of perplexity that brought me , in a few weeks , to the confines of distraction .
Parsing [sent. 11876 len. 76]: The changes that were rung upon dots , which in such a position meant such a thing , and in such another position something else , entirely different ; the wonderful vagaries that were played by circles ; the unaccountable consequences that resulted from marks like flies ' legs ; the tremendous effects of a curve in a wrong place ; not only troubled my waking hours , but reappeared before me in my sleep .
Parsing [sent. 11877 len. 78]: When I had groped my way , blindly , through these difficulties , and had mastered the alphabet , which was an Egyptian Temple in itself , there then appeared a procession of new horrors , called arbitrary characters ; the most despotic characters I have ever known ; who insisted , for instance , that a thing like the beginning of a cobweb , meant expectation , and that a pen-and-ink sky-rocket , stood for disadvantageous .
Parsing [sent. 11878 len. 55]: When I had fixed these wretches in my mind , I found that they had driven everything else out of it ; then , beginning again , I forgot them ; while I was picking them up , I dropped the other fragments of the system ; in short , it was almost heart-breaking .

Parsing [sent. 12259 len. 56]: There were a number of hangers-on and outsiders about the Commons , who , without being proctors themselves , dabbled in common-form business , and got it done by real proctors , who lent their names in consideration of a share in the spoil ; -- and there were a good many of these too .
Parsing [sent. 12260 len. 33]: As our house now wanted business on any terms , we joined this noble band ; and threw out lures to the hangers-on and outsiders , to bring their business to us .
Parsing [sent. 12261 len. 28]: Marriage licences and small probates were what we all looked for , and what paid us best ; and the competition for these ran very high indeed .
Parsing [sent. 12262 len. 82]: Kidnappers and inveiglers were planted in all the avenues of entrance to the Commons , with instructions to do their utmost to cut off all persons in mourning , and all gentlemen with anything bashful in their appearance , and entice them to the offices in which their respective employers were interested ; which instructions were so well observed , that I myself , before I was known by sight , was twice hustled into the premises of our principal opponent .
Parsing [sent. 12263 len. 59]: The conflicting interests of these touting gentlemen being of a nature to irritate their feelings , personal collisions took place ; and the Commons was even scandalized by our principal inveigler -LRB- who had formerly been in the wine trade , and afterwards in the sworn brokery line -RRB- walking about for some days with a black eye .

Parsing [sent. 13252 len. 54]: Chapter 42 Mischief I feel as if it were not for me to record , even though this manuscript is intended for no eyes but mine , how hard I worked at that tremendous short-hand , and all improvement appertaining to it , in my sense of responsibility to Dora and her aunts .
Parsing [sent. 13253 len. 73]: I will only add , to what I have already written of my perseverance at this time of my life , and of a patient and continuous energy which then began to be matured within me , and which I know to be the strong part of my character , if it have any strength at all , that there , on looking back , I find the source of my success .
Parsing [sent. 13254 len. 75]: I have been very fortunate in worldly matters ; many men have worked much harder , and not succeeded half so well ; but I never could have done what I have done , without the habits of punctuality , order , and diligence , without the determination to concentrate myself on one object at a time , no matter how quickly its successor should come upon its heels , which I then formed .
Parsing [sent. 13255 len. 12]: Heaven knows I write this , in no spirit of self-laudation .
Parsing [sent. 13256 len. 66]: The man who reviews his own life , as I do mine , in going on here , from page to page , had need to have been a good man indeed , if he would be spared the sharp consciousness of many talents neglected , many opportunities wasted , many erratic and perverted feelings constantly at war within his breast , and defeating him .
Parsing [sent. 13257 len. 18]: I do not hold one natural gift , I dare say , that I have not abused .
Parsing [sent. 13258 len. 57]: My meaning simply is , that whatever I have tried to do in life , I have tried with all my heart to do well ; that whatever I have devoted myself to , I have devoted myself to completely ; that in great aims and in small , I have always been thoroughly in earnest .
Parsing [sent. 13259 len. 34]: I have never believed it possible that any natural or improved ability can claim immunity from the companionship of the steady , plain , hard-working qualities , and hope to gain its end .

Parsing [sent. 13646 len. 182]: When I think of him , with his impenetrably wise face , walking up and down with the Doctor , delighted to be battered by the hard words in the Dictionary ; when I think of him carrying huge watering-pots after Annie ; kneeling down , in very paws of gloves , at patient microscopic work among the little leaves ; expressing as no philosopher could have expressed , in everything he did , a delicate desire to be her friend ; showering sympathy , trustfulness , and affection , out of every hole in the watering-pot ; when I think of him never wandering in that better mind of his to which unhappiness addressed itself , never bringing the unfortunate King Charles into the garden , never wavering in his grateful service , never diverted from his knowledge that there was something wrong , or from his wish to set it right - I really feel almost ashamed of having known that he was not quite in his wits , taking account of the utmost I have done with mine .

Parsing [sent. 13676 len. 18]: Chapter 43 Another Retrospect Once again , let me pause upon a memorable period of my life .
Parsing [sent. 13677 len. 26]: Let me stand aside , to see the phantoms of those days go by me , accompanying the shadow of myself , in dim procession .
Parsing [sent. 13678 len. 9]: Weeks , months , seasons , pass along .
Parsing [sent. 13679 len. 13]: They seem little more than a summer day and a winter evening .
Parsing [sent. 13680 len. 36]: Now , the Common where I walk with Dora is all in bloom , a field of bright gold ; and now the unseen heather lies in mounds and bunches underneath a covering of snow .
Parsing [sent. 13681 len. 34]: In a breath , the river that flows through our Sunday walks is sparkling in the summer sun , is ruffled by the winter wind , or thickened with drifting heaps of ice .
Parsing [sent. 13682 len. 18]: Faster than ever river ran towards the sea , it flashes , darkens , and rolls away .
Parsing [sent. 13683 len. 15]: Not a thread changes , in the house of the two little bird-like ladies .
Parsing [sent. 13684 len. 14]: The clock ticks over the fireplace , the weather-glass hangs in the hall .
Parsing [sent. 13685 len. 16]: Neither clock nor weather-glass is ever right ; but we believe in both , devoutly .
Parsing [sent. 13686 len. 9]: I have come legally to man 's estate .
Parsing [sent. 13687 len. 8]: I have attained the dignity of twenty-one .
Parsing [sent. 13688 len. 14]: But this is a sort of dignity that may be thrust upon one .
Parsing [sent. 13689 len. 8]: Let me think what I have achieved .
Parsing [sent. 13690 len. 8]: I have tamed that savage stenographic mystery .
Parsing [sent. 13691 len. 8]: I make a respectable income by it .
Parsing [sent. 13692 len. 32]: I am in high repute for my accomplishment in all pertaining to the art , and am joined with eleven others in reporting the debates in Parliament for a Morning Newspaper .
Parsing [sent. 13693 len. 27]: Night after night , I record predictions that never come to pass , professions that are never fulfilled , explanations that are only meant to mystify .
Parsing [sent. 13694 len. 5]: I wallow in words .
Parsing [sent. 13695 len. 32]: Britannia , that unfortunate female , is always before me , like a trussed fowl : skewered through and through with office-pens , and bound hand and foot with red tape .
Parsing [sent. 13696 len. 14]: I am sufficiently behind the scenes to know the worth of political life .
Parsing [sent. 13697 len. 14]: I am quite an Infidel about it , and shall never be converted .
Parsing [sent. 13698 len. 22]: My dear old Traddles has tried his hand at the same pursuit , but it is not in Traddles 's way .
Parsing [sent. 13699 len. 19]: He is perfectly good-humoured respecting his failure , and reminds me that he always did consider himself slow .
Parsing [sent. 13700 len. 29]: He has occasional employment on the same newspaper , in getting up the facts of dry subjects , to be written about and embellished by more fertile minds .
Parsing [sent. 13701 len. 29]: He is called to the bar ; and with admirable industry and self-denial has scraped another hundred pounds together , to fee a Conveyancer whose chambers he attends .
Parsing [sent. 13702 len. 34]: A great deal of very hot port wine was consumed at his call ; and , considering the figure , I should think the Inner Temple must have made a profit by it .
Parsing [sent. 13703 len. 8]: I have come out in another way .
Parsing [sent. 13704 len. 10]: I have taken with fear and trembling to authorship .
Parsing [sent. 13705 len. 24]: I wrote a little something , in secret , and sent it to a magazine , and it was published in the magazine .
Parsing [sent. 13706 len. 15]: Since then , I have taken heart to write a good many trifling pieces .
Parsing [sent. 13707 len. 9]: Now , I am regularly paid for them .
Parsing [sent. 13708 len. 35]: Altogether , I am well off , when I tell my income on the fingers of my left hand , I pass the third finger and take in the fourth to the middle joint .
Parsing [sent. 13709 len. 28]: We have removed , from Buckingham Street , to a pleasant little cottage very near the one I looked at , when my enthusiasm first came on .
Parsing [sent. 13710 len. 39]: My aunt , however -LRB- who has sold the house at Dover , to good advantage -RRB- , is not going to remain here , but intends removing herself to a still more tiny cottage close at hand .
Parsing [sent. 13711 len. 5]: What does this portend ?
Parsing [sent. 13712 len. 3]: My marriage ?
Parsing [sent. 13713 len. 2]: Yes !
Parsing [sent. 13714 len. 2]: Yes !
Parsing [sent. 13715 len. 9]: I am going to be married to Dora !
Parsing [sent. 13716 len. 23]: Miss Lavinia and Miss Clarissa have given their consent ; and if ever canary birds were in a flutter , they are .
Parsing [sent. 13717 len. 44]: Miss Lavinia , self-charged with the superintendence of my darling 's wardrobe , is constantly cutting out brown-paper cuirasses , and differing in opinion from a highly respectable young man , with a long bundle , and a yard measure under his arm .
Parsing [sent. 13718 len. 40]: A dressmaker , always stabbed in the breast with a needle and thread , boards and lodges in the house ; and seems to me , eating , drinking , or sleeping , never to take her thimble off .
Parsing [sent. 13719 len. 8]: They make a lay-figure of my dear .
Parsing [sent. 13720 len. 13]: They are always sending for her to come and try something on .
Parsing [sent. 13721 len. 41]: We ca n't be happy together for five minutes in the evening , but some intrusive female knocks at the door , and says , ` Oh , if you please , Miss Dora , would you step upstairs ! '
Parsing [sent. 13722 len. 24]: Miss Clarissa and my aunt roam all over London , to find out articles of furniture for Dora and me to look at .
Parsing [sent. 13723 len. 51]: It would be better for them to buy the goods at once , without this ceremony of inspection ; for , when we go to see a kitchen fender and meat-screen , Dora sees a Chinese house for Jip , with little bells on the top , and prefers that .
Parsing [sent. 13724 len. 40]: And it takes a long time to accustom Jip to his new residence , after we have bought it ; whenever he goes in or out , he makes all the little bells ring , and is horribly frightened .
Parsing [sent. 13725 len. 14]: Peggotty comes up to make herself useful , and falls to work immediately .
Parsing [sent. 13726 len. 14]: Her department appears to be , to clean everything over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 13727 len. 22]: She rubs everything that can be rubbed , until it shines , like her own honest forehead , with perpetual friction .
Parsing [sent. 13728 len. 33]: And now it is , that I begin to see her solitary brother passing through the dark streets at night , and looking , as he goes , among the wandering faces .
Parsing [sent. 13729 len. 10]: I never speak to him at such an hour .
Parsing [sent. 13730 len. 21]: I know too well , as his grave figure passes onward , what he seeks , and what he dreads .
Parsing [sent. 13731 len. 33]: Why does Traddles look so important when he calls upon me this afternoon in the Commons -- where I still occasionally attend , for form 's sake , when I have time ?
Parsing [sent. 13732 len. 10]: The realization of my boyish day-dreams is at hand .
Parsing [sent. 13733 len. 9]: I am going to take out the licence .
Parsing [sent. 13734 len. 30]: It is a little document to do so much ; and Traddles contemplates it , as it lies upon my desk , half in admiration , half in awe .
Parsing [sent. 13735 len. 79]: There are the names , in the sweet old visionary connexion , David Copperfield and Dora Spenlow ; and there , in the corner , is that Parental Institution , the Stamp Office , which is so benignantly interested in the various transactions of human life , looking down upon our Union ; and there is the Archbishop of Canterbury invoking a blessing on us in print , and doing it as cheap as could possibly be expected .
Parsing [sent. 13736 len. 16]: Nevertheless , I am in a dream , a flustered , happy , hurried dream .
Parsing [sent. 13737 len. 44]: I ca n't believe that it is going to be ; and yet I ca n't believe but that everyone I pass in the street , must have some kind of perception , that I am to be married the day after tomorrow .
Parsing [sent. 13738 len. 29]: The Surrogate knows me , when I go down to be sworn ; and disposes of me easily , as if there were a Masonic understanding between us .
Parsing [sent. 13739 len. 17]: Traddles is not at all wanted , but is in attendance as my general backer . '
Parsing [sent. 13740 len. 30]: I hope the next time you come here , my dear fellow , ' I say to Traddles , ` it will be on the same errand for yourself .
Parsing [sent. 13741 len. 9]: And I hope it will be soon . '
Parsing [sent. 13742 len. 17]: ` Thank you for your good wishes , my dear Copperfield , ' he replies . '
Parsing [sent. 13743 len. 5]: I hope so too .
Parsing [sent. 13744 len. 39]: It 's a satisfaction to know that she 'll wait for me any length of time , and that she really is the dearest girl -- ' ` When are you to meet her at the coach ? '
Parsing [sent. 13745 len. 3]: I ask .
Parsing [sent. 13746 len. 35]: ` At seven , ' says Traddles , looking at his plain old silver watch -- the very watch he once took a wheel out of , at school , to make a water-mill .
Parsing [sent. 13747 len. 15]: ` That is about Miss Wickfield 's time , is it not ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 13748 len. 4]: A little earlier .
Parsing [sent. 13749 len. 9]: Her time is half past eight . ' '
Parsing [sent. 13750 len. 41]: I assure you , my dear boy , ' says Traddles , ' I am almost as pleased as if I were going to be married myself , to think that this event is coming to such a happy termination .
Parsing [sent. 13751 len. 34]: And really the great friendship and consideration of personally associating Sophy with the joyful occasion , and inviting her to be a bridesmaid in conjunction with Miss Wickfield , demands my warmest thanks .
Parsing [sent. 13752 len. 8]: I am extremely sensible of it . '
Parsing [sent. 13753 len. 31]: I hear him , and shake hands with him ; and we talk , and walk , and dine , and so on ; but I do n't believe it .
Parsing [sent. 13754 len. 4]: Nothing is real .
Parsing [sent. 13755 len. 14]: Sophy arrives at the house of Dora 's aunts , in due course .
Parsing [sent. 13756 len. 37]: She has the most agreeable of faces , -- not absolutely beautiful , but extraordinarily pleasant , -- and is one of the most genial , unaffected , frank , engaging creatures I have ever seen .
Parsing [sent. 13757 len. 42]: Traddles presents her to us with great pride ; and rubs his hands for ten minutes by the clock , with every individual hair upon his head standing on tiptoe , when I congratulate him in a corner on his choice .
Parsing [sent. 13758 len. 23]: I have brought Agnes from the Canterbury coach , and her cheerful and beautiful face is among us for the second time .
Parsing [sent. 13759 len. 37]: Agnes has a great liking for Traddles , and it is capital to see them meet , and to observe the glory of Traddles as he commends the dearest girl in the world to her acquaintance .
Parsing [sent. 13760 len. 7]: Still I do n't believe it .
Parsing [sent. 13761 len. 19]: We have a delightful evening , and are supremely happy ; but I do n't believe it yet .
Parsing [sent. 13762 len. 6]: I ca n't collect myself .
Parsing [sent. 13763 len. 12]: I ca n't check off my happiness as it takes place .
Parsing [sent. 13764 len. 36]: I feel in a misty and unsettled kind of state ; as if I had got up very early in the morning a week or two ago , and had never been to bed since .
Parsing [sent. 13765 len. 9]: I ca n't make out when yesterday was .
Parsing [sent. 13766 len. 17]: I seem to have been carrying the licence about , in my pocket , many months .
Parsing [sent. 13767 len. 36]: Next day , too , when we all go in a flock to see the house -- our house -- Dora 's and mine -- I am quite unable to regard myself as its master .
Parsing [sent. 13768 len. 12]: I seem to be there , by permission of somebody else .
Parsing [sent. 13769 len. 20]: I half expect the real master to come home presently , and say he is glad to see me .
Parsing [sent. 13770 len. 85]: Such a beautiful little house as it is , with everything so bright and new ; with the flowers on the carpets looking as if freshly gathered , and the green leaves on the paper as if they had just come out ; with the spotless muslin curtains , and the blushing rose-coloured furniture , and Dora 's garden hat with the blue ribbon -- do I remember , now , how I loved her in such another hat when I first knew her !
Parsing [sent. 13771 len. 37]: -- already hanging on its little peg ; the guitar-case quite at home on its heels in a corner ; and everybody tumbling over Jip 's pagoda , which is much too big for the establishment .
Parsing [sent. 13772 len. 25]: Another happy evening , quite as unreal as all the rest of it , and I steal into the usual room before going away .
Parsing [sent. 13773 len. 5]: Dora is not there .
Parsing [sent. 13774 len. 10]: I suppose they have not done trying on yet .
Parsing [sent. 13775 len. 16]: Miss Lavinia peeps in , and tells me mysteriously that she will not be long .
Parsing [sent. 13776 len. 23]: She is rather long , notwithstanding ; but by and by I hear a rustling at the door , and someone taps .
Parsing [sent. 13777 len. 8]: I say , ` Come in ! '
Parsing [sent. 13778 len. 5]: but someone taps again .
Parsing [sent. 13779 len. 54]: I go to the door , wondering who it is ; there , I meet a pair of bright eyes , and a blushing face ; they are Dora 's eyes and face , and Miss Lavinia has dressed her in tomorrow 's dress , bonnet and all , for me to see .
Parsing [sent. 13780 len. 44]: I take my little wife to my heart ; and Miss Lavinia gives a little scream because I tumble the bonnet , and Dora laughs and cries at once , because I am so pleased ; and I believe it less than ever .
Parsing [sent. 13781 len. 10]: ` Do you think it pretty , Doady ? '
Parsing [sent. 13782 len. 3]: says Dora .
Parsing [sent. 13783 len. 2]: Pretty !
Parsing [sent. 13784 len. 7]: I should rather think I did .
Parsing [sent. 13785 len. 12]: ` And are you sure you like me very much ? '
Parsing [sent. 13786 len. 3]: says Dora .
Parsing [sent. 13787 len. 41]: The topic is fraught with such danger to the bonnet , that Miss Lavinia gives another little scream , and begs me to understand that Dora is only to be looked at , and on no account to be touched .
Parsing [sent. 13788 len. 32]: So Dora stands in a delightful state of confusion for a minute or two , to be admired ; and then takes off her bonnet -- looking so natural without it !
Parsing [sent. 13789 len. 63]: -- and runs away with it in her hand ; and comes dancing down again in her own familiar dress , and asks Jip if I have got a beautiful little wife , and whether he 'll forgive her for being married , and kneels down to make him stand upon the cookery-book , for the last time in her single life .
Parsing [sent. 13790 len. 38]: I go home , more incredulous than ever , to a lodging that I have hard by ; and get up very early in the morning , to ride to the Highgate road and fetch my aunt .
Parsing [sent. 13791 len. 10]: I have never seen my aunt in such state .
Parsing [sent. 13792 len. 18]: She is dressed in lavender-coloured silk , and has a white bonnet on , and is amazing .
Parsing [sent. 13793 len. 13]: Janet has dressed her , and is there to look at me .
Parsing [sent. 13794 len. 17]: Peggotty is ready to go to church , intending to behold the ceremony from the gallery .
Parsing [sent. 13795 len. 21]: Mr. Dick , who is to give my darling to me at the altar , has had his hair curled .
Parsing [sent. 13796 len. 41]: Traddles , whom I have taken up by appointment at the turnpike , presents a dazzling combination of cream colour and light blue ; and both he and Mr. Dick have a general effect about them of being all gloves .
Parsing [sent. 13797 len. 24]: No doubt I see this , because I know it is so ; but I am astray , and seem to see nothing .
Parsing [sent. 13798 len. 7]: Nor do I believe anything whatever .
Parsing [sent. 13799 len. 51]: Still , as we drive along in an open carriage , this fairy marriage is real enough to fill me with a sort of wondering pity for the unfortunate people who have no part in it , but are sweeping out the shops , and going to their daily occupations .
Parsing [sent. 13800 len. 12]: My aunt sits with my hand in hers all the way .

Parsing [sent. 13803 len. 8]: My own boy never could be dearer .

Parsing [sent. 13805 len. 16]: ` So do I. And of all I owe to you , dear aunt . '

Parsing [sent. 13807 len. 45]: says my aunt ; and gives her hand in overflowing cordiality to Traddles , who then gives his to Mr. Dick , who then gives his to me , who then gives mine to Traddles , and then we come to the church door .
Parsing [sent. 13808 len. 30]: The church is calm enough , I am sure ; but it might be a steam-power loom in full action , for any sedative effect it has on me .
Parsing [sent. 13809 len. 8]: I am too far gone for that .
Parsing [sent. 13810 len. 11]: The rest is all a more or less incoherent dream .
Parsing [sent. 13811 len. 71]: A dream of their coming in with Dora ; of the pew-opener arranging us , like a drill-sergeant , before the altar rails ; of my wondering , even then , why pew-openers must always be the most disagreeable females procurable , and whether there is any religious dread of a disastrous infection of good-humour which renders it indispensable to set those vessels of vinegar upon the road to Heaven .
Parsing [sent. 13812 len. 48]: Of the clergyman and clerk appearing ; of a few boatmen and some other people strolling in ; of an ancient mariner behind me , strongly flavouring the church with rum ; of the service beginning in a deep voice , and our all being very attentive .

Parsing [sent. 13817 len. 58]: Of my walking so proudly and lovingly down the aisle with my sweet wife upon my arm , through a mist of half-seen people , pulpits , monuments , pews , fonts , organs , and church windows , in which there flutter faint airs of association with my childish church at home , so long ago .
Parsing [sent. 13818 len. 24]: Of their whispering , as we pass , what a youthful couple we are , and what a pretty little wife she is .

Parsing [sent. 13820 len. 44]: Of Sophy telling us that when she saw Traddles -LRB- whom I had entrusted with the licence -RRB- asked for it , she almost fainted , having been convinced that he would contrive to lose it , or to have his pocket picked .
Parsing [sent. 13821 len. 28]: Of Agnes laughing gaily ; and of Dora being so fond of Agnes that she will not be separated from her , but still keeps her hand .
Parsing [sent. 13822 len. 68]: Of there being a breakfast , with abundance of things , pretty and substantial , to eat and drink , whereof I partake , as I should do in any other dream , without the least perception of their flavour ; eating and drinking , as I may say , nothing but love and marriage , and no more believing in the viands than in anything else .
Parsing [sent. 13823 len. 39]: Of my making a speech in the same dreamy fashion , without having an idea of what I want to say , beyond such as may be comprehended in the full conviction that I have n't said it .

Parsing [sent. 13825 len. 20]: Of the pair of hired post-horses being ready , and of Dora 's going away to change her dress .
Parsing [sent. 13826 len. 48]: Of my aunt and Miss Clarissa remaining with us ; and our walking in the garden ; and my aunt , who has made quite a speech at breakfast touching Dora 's aunts , being mightily amused with herself , but a little proud of it too .

Parsing [sent. 13843 len. 59]: Chapter 44 Our Housekeeping It was a strange condition of things , the honeymoon being over , and the bridesmaids gone home , when I found myself sitting down in my own small house with Dora ; quite thrown out of employment , as I may say , in respect of the delicious old occupation of making love .
Parsing [sent. 13844 len. 12]: It seemed such an extraordinary thing to have Dora always there .
Parsing [sent. 13845 len. 48]: It was so unaccountable not to be obliged to go out to see her , not to have any occasion to be tormenting myself about her , not to have to write to her , not to be scheming and devising opportunities of being alone with her .
Parsing [sent. 13846 len. 83]: Sometimes of an evening , when I looked up from my writing , and saw her seated opposite , I would lean back in my chair , and think how queer it was that there we were , alone together as a matter of course -- nobody 's business any more -- all the romance of our engagement put away upon a shelf , to rust -- no one to please but one another -- one another to please , for life .
Parsing [sent. 13847 len. 35]: When there was a debate , and I was kept out very late , it seemed so strange to me , as I was walking home , to think that Dora was at home !
Parsing [sent. 13848 len. 26]: It was such a wonderful thing , at first , to have her coming softly down to talk to me as I ate my supper .
Parsing [sent. 13849 len. 18]: It was such a stupendous thing to know for certain that she put her hair in papers .
Parsing [sent. 13850 len. 13]: It was altogether such an astonishing event to see her do it !
Parsing [sent. 13851 len. 22]: I doubt whether two young birds could have known less about keeping house , than I and my pretty Dora did .
Parsing [sent. 13852 len. 8]: We had a servant , of course .
Parsing [sent. 13853 len. 6]: She kept house for us .
Parsing [sent. 13854 len. 30]: I have still a latent belief that she must have been Mrs. Crupp 's daughter in disguise , we had such an awful time of it with Mary Anne .
Parsing [sent. 13855 len. 5]: Her name was Paragon .
Parsing [sent. 13856 len. 20]: Her nature was represented to us , when we engaged her , as being feebly expressed in her name .
Parsing [sent. 13857 len. 44]: She had a written character , as large as a proclamation ; and , according to this document , could do everything of a domestic nature that ever I heard of , and a great many things that I never did hear of .
Parsing [sent. 13858 len. 33]: She was a woman in the prime of life ; of a severe countenance ; and subject -LRB- particularly in the arms -RRB- to a sort of perpetual measles or fiery rash .
Parsing [sent. 13859 len. 23]: She had a cousin in the Life-Guards , with such long legs that he looked like the afternoon shadow of somebody else .
Parsing [sent. 13860 len. 18]: His shell-jacket was as much too little for him as he was too big for the premises .
Parsing [sent. 13861 len. 22]: He made the cottage smaller than it need have been , by being so very much out of proportion to it .
Parsing [sent. 13862 len. 34]: Besides which , the walls were not thick , and , whenever he passed the evening at our house , we always knew of it by hearing one continual growl in the kitchen .
Parsing [sent. 13863 len. 8]: Our treasure was warranted sober and honest .
Parsing [sent. 13864 len. 31]: I am therefore willing to believe that she was in a fit when we found her under the boiler ; and that the deficient tea-spoons were attributable to the dustman .
Parsing [sent. 13865 len. 8]: But she preyed upon our minds dreadfully .
Parsing [sent. 13866 len. 12]: We felt our inexperience , and were unable to help ourselves .
Parsing [sent. 13867 len. 25]: We should have been at her mercy , if she had had any ; but she was a remorseless woman , and had none .
Parsing [sent. 13868 len. 10]: She was the cause of our first little quarrel .
Parsing [sent. 13869 len. 26]: ` My dearest life , ' I said one day to Dora , ` do you think Mary Anne has any idea of time ? '
Parsing [sent. 13870 len. 6]: ` Why , Doady ? '
Parsing [sent. 13871 len. 12]: inquired Dora , looking up , innocently , from her drawing .
Parsing [sent. 13872 len. 19]: ` My love , because it 's five , and we were to have dined at four . '
Parsing [sent. 13873 len. 17]: Dora glanced wistfully at the clock , and hinted that she thought it was too fast .
Parsing [sent. 13874 len. 27]: ` On the contrary , my love , ' said I , referring to my watch , ` it 's a few minutes too slow . '
Parsing [sent. 13875 len. 45]: My little wife came and sat upon my knee , to coax me to be quiet , and drew a line with her pencil down the middle of my nose ; but I could n't dine off that , though it was very agreeable .
Parsing [sent. 13876 len. 27]: ` Do n't you think , my dear , ' said I , ` it would be better for you to remonstrate with Mary Anne ? '
Parsing [sent. 13877 len. 6]: ` Oh no , please !
Parsing [sent. 13878 len. 7]: I could n't , Doady ! '
Parsing [sent. 13879 len. 3]: said Dora .
Parsing [sent. 13880 len. 8]: ` Why not , my love ? '
Parsing [sent. 13881 len. 4]: I gently asked .
Parsing [sent. 13882 len. 23]: ` Oh , because I am such a little goose , ' said Dora , ` and she knows I am ! '
Parsing [sent. 13883 len. 24]: I thought this sentiment so incompatible with the establishment of any system of check on Mary Anne , that I frowned a little .
Parsing [sent. 13884 len. 14]: ` Oh , what ugly wrinkles in my bad boy 's forehead ! '
Parsing [sent. 13885 len. 52]: said Dora , and still being on my knee , she traced them with her pencil ; putting it to her rosy lips to make it mark blacker , and working at my forehead with a quaint little mockery of being industrious , that quite delighted me in spite of myself .
Parsing [sent. 13886 len. 23]: ` There 's a good child , ' said Dora , ` it makes its face so much prettier to laugh . '

Parsing [sent. 14570 len. 23]: I had often passed it before , during my residence in that neighbourhood , though never when I could choose another road .
Parsing [sent. 14571 len. 36]: Howbeit , it did sometimes happen that it was not easy to find another , without making a long circuit ; and so I had passed that way , upon the whole , pretty often .

Parsing [sent. 14573 len. 8]: It had been uniformly gloomy and dull .
Parsing [sent. 14574 len. 39]: None of the best rooms abutted on the road ; and the narrow , heavily-framed old-fashioned windows , never cheerful under any circumstances , looked very dismal , close shut , and with their blinds always drawn down .
Parsing [sent. 14575 len. 51]: There was a covered way across a little paved court , to an entrance that was never used ; and there was one round staircase window , at odds with all the rest , and the only one unshaded by a blind , which had the same unoccupied blank look .

Parsing [sent. 17322 len. 50]: We came to Ipswich -- very late , having had to fight every inch of ground since we were ten miles out of London ; and found a cluster of people in the market-place , who had risen from their beds in the night , fearful of falling chimneys .
Parsing [sent. 17323 len. 40]: Some of these , congregating about the inn-yard while we changed horses , told us of great sheets of lead having been ripped off a high church-tower , and flung into a by-street , which they then blocked up .

Parsing [sent. 17325 len. 15]: Still , there was no abatement in the storm , but it blew harder .

Parsing [sent. 17330 len. 39]: When at last we got into the town , the people came out to their doors , all aslant , and with streaming hair , making a wonder of the mail that had come through such a night .
Parsing [sent. 17331 len. 55]: I put up at the old inn , and went down to look at the sea ; staggering along the street , which was strewn with sand and seaweed , and with flying blotches of sea-foam ; afraid of falling slates and tiles ; and holding by people I met , at angry corners .
Parsing [sent. 17332 len. 56]: Coming near the beach , I saw , not only the boatmen , but half the people of the town , lurking behind buildings ; some , now and then braving the fury of the storm to look away to sea , and blown sheer out of their course in trying to get zigzag back .
Parsing [sent. 17333 len. 38]: joining these groups , I found bewailing women whose husbands were away in herring or oyster boats , which there was too much reason to think might have foundered before they could run in anywhere for safety .
Parsing [sent. 17334 len. 71]: Grizzled old sailors were among the people , shaking their heads , as they looked from water to sky , and muttering to one another ; ship-owners , excited and uneasy ; children , huddling together , and peering into older faces ; even stout mariners , disturbed and anxious , levelling their glasses at the sea from behind places of shelter , as if they were surveying an enemy .
Parsing [sent. 17335 len. 38]: The tremendous sea itself , when I could find sufficient pause to look at it , in the agitation of the blinding wind , the flying stones and sand , and the awful noise , confounded me .
Parsing [sent. 17336 len. 30]: As the high watery walls came rolling in , and , at their highest , tumbled into surf , they looked as if the least would engulf the town .
Parsing [sent. 17337 len. 32]: As the receding wave swept back with a hoarse roar , it seemed to scoop out deep caves in the beach , as if its purpose were to undermine the earth .
Parsing [sent. 17338 len. 45]: When some white-headed billows thundered on , and dashed themselves to pieces before they reached the land , every fragment of the late whole seemed possessed by the full might of its wrath , rushing to be gathered to the composition of another monster .
Parsing [sent. 17339 len. 100]: Undulating hills were changed to valleys , undulating valleys -LRB- with a solitary storm-bird sometimes skimming through them -RRB- were lifted up to hills ; masses of water shivered and shook the beach with a booming sound ; every shape tumultuously rolled on , as soon as made , to change its shape and place , and beat another shape and place away ; the ideal shore on the horizon , with its towers and buildings , rose and fell ; the clouds fell fast and thick ; I seemed to see a rending and upheaving of all nature .
Parsing [sent. 17340 len. 42]: Not finding Ham among the people whom this memorable wind -- for it is still remembered down there , as the greatest ever known to blow upon that coast -- had brought together , I made my way to his house .
Parsing [sent. 17341 len. 29]: It was shut ; and as no one answered to my knocking , I went , by back ways and by-lanes , to the yard where he worked .
Parsing [sent. 17342 len. 39]: I learned , there , that he had gone to Lowestoft , to meet some sudden exigency of ship-repairing in which his skill was required ; but that he would be back tomorrow morning , in good time .
Parsing [sent. 17343 len. 32]: I went back to the inn ; and when I had washed and dressed , and tried to sleep , but in vain , it was five o'clock in the afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 17344 len. 70]: I had not sat five minutes by the coffee-room fire , when the waiter , coming to stir it , as an excuse for talking , told me that two colliers had gone down , with all hands , a few miles away ; and that some other ships had been seen labouring hard in the Roads , and trying , in great distress , to keep off shore .
Parsing [sent. 17345 len. 22]: Mercy on them , and on all poor sailors , said he , if we had another night like the last !
Parsing [sent. 17346 len. 27]: I was very much depressed in spirits ; very solitary ; and felt an uneasiness in Ham 's not being there , disproportionate to the occasion .
Parsing [sent. 17347 len. 26]: I was seriously affected , without knowing how much , by late events ; and my long exposure to the fierce wind had confused me .
Parsing [sent. 17348 len. 22]: There was that jumble in my thoughts and recollections , that I had lost the clear arrangement of time and distance .
Parsing [sent. 17349 len. 33]: Thus , if I had gone out into the town , I should not have been surprised , I think , to encounter someone who I knew must be then in London .
Parsing [sent. 17350 len. 16]: So to speak , there was in these respects a curious inattention in my mind .
Parsing [sent. 17351 len. 24]: Yet it was busy , too , with all the remembrances the place naturally awakened ; and they were particularly distinct and vivid .
Parsing [sent. 17352 len. 29]: In this state , the waiter 's dismal intelligence about the ships immediately connected itself , without any effort of my volition , with my uneasiness about Ham .
Parsing [sent. 17353 len. 20]: I was persuaded that I had an apprehension of his returning from Lowestoft by sea , and being lost .
Parsing [sent. 17354 len. 39]: This grew so strong with me , that I resolved to go back to the yard before I took my dinner , and ask the boat-builder if he thought his attempting to return by sea at all likely ?
Parsing [sent. 17355 len. 26]: If he gave me the least reason to think so , I would go over to Lowestoft and prevent it by bringing him with me .
Parsing [sent. 17356 len. 13]: I hastily ordered my dinner , and went back to the yard .
Parsing [sent. 17357 len. 22]: I was none too soon ; for the boat-builder , with a lantern in his hand , was locking the yard-gate .
Parsing [sent. 17358 len. 51]: He quite laughed when I asked him the question , and said there was no fear ; no man in his senses , or out of them , would put off in such a gale of wind , least of all Ham Peggotty , who had been born to seafaring .
Parsing [sent. 17359 len. 30]: So sensible of this , beforehand , that I had really felt ashamed of doing what I was nevertheless impelled to do , I went back to the inn .
Parsing [sent. 17360 len. 13]: If such a wind could rise , I think it was rising .
Parsing [sent. 17361 len. 46]: The howl and roar , the rattling of the doors and windows , the rumbling in the chimneys , the apparent rocking of the very house that sheltered me , and the prodigious tumult of the sea , were more fearful than in the morning .
Parsing [sent. 17362 len. 22]: But there was now a great darkness besides ; and that invested the storm with new terrors , real and fanciful .
Parsing [sent. 17363 len. 19]: I could not eat , I could not sit still , I could not continue steadfast to anything .
Parsing [sent. 17364 len. 25]: Something within me , faintly answering to the storm without , tossed up the depths of my memory and made a tumult in them .
Parsing [sent. 17365 len. 32]: Yet , in all the hurry of my thoughts , wild running with the thundering sea , -- the storm , and my uneasiness regarding Ham were always in the fore-ground .
Parsing [sent. 17366 len. 21]: My dinner went away almost untasted , and I tried to refresh myself with a glass or two of wine .
Parsing [sent. 17367 len. 3]: In vain .
Parsing [sent. 17368 len. 32]: I fell into a dull slumber before the fire , without losing my consciousness , either of the uproar out of doors , or of the place in which I was .
Parsing [sent. 17369 len. 40]: Both became overshadowed by a new and indefinable horror ; and when I awoke -- or rather when I shook off the lethargy that bound me in my chair - my whole frame thrilled with objectless and unintelligible fear .
Parsing [sent. 17370 len. 31]: I walked to and fro , tried to read an old gazetteer , listened to the awful noises : looked at faces , scenes , and figures in the fire .
Parsing [sent. 17371 len. 26]: At length , the steady ticking of the undisturbed clock on the wall tormented me to that degree that I resolved to go to bed .
Parsing [sent. 17372 len. 26]: It was reassuring , on such a night , to be told that some of the inn-servants had agreed together to sit up until morning .
Parsing [sent. 17373 len. 38]: I went to bed , exceedingly weary and heavy ; but , on my lying down , all such sensations vanished , as if by magic , and I was broad awake , with every sense refined .
Parsing [sent. 17374 len. 48]: For hours I lay there , listening to the wind and water ; imagining , now , that I heard shrieks out at sea ; now , that I distinctly heard the firing of signal guns ; and now , the fall of houses in the town .
Parsing [sent. 17375 len. 46]: I got up , several times , and looked out ; but could see nothing , except the reflection in the window-panes of the faint candle I had left burning , and of my own haggard face looking in at me from the black void .
Parsing [sent. 17376 len. 22]: At length , my restlessness attained to such a pitch , that I hurried on my clothes , and went downstairs .

Parsing [sent. 17378 len. 51]: A pretty girl , who had her ears stopped with her apron , and her eyes upon the door , screamed when I appeared , supposing me to be a spirit ; but the others had more presence of mind , and were glad of an addition to their company .

Parsing [sent. 17380 len. 11]: I remained there , I dare say , two hours .
Parsing [sent. 17381 len. 14]: Once , I opened the yard-gate , and looked into the empty street .
Parsing [sent. 17382 len. 40]: The sand , the sea-weed , and the flakes of foam , were driving by ; and I was obliged to call for assistance before I could shut the gate again , and make it fast against the wind .
Parsing [sent. 17383 len. 47]: There was a dark gloom in my solitary chamber , when I at length returned to it ; but I was tired now , and , getting into bed again , fell -- off a tower and down a precipice -- into the depths of sleep .
Parsing [sent. 17384 len. 31]: I have an impression that for a long time , though I dreamed of being elsewhere and in a variety of scenes , it was always blowing in my dream .
Parsing [sent. 17385 len. 40]: At length , I lost that feeble hold upon reality , and was engaged with two dear friends , but who they were I do n't know , at the siege of some town in a roar of cannonading .
Parsing [sent. 17386 len. 32]: The thunder of the cannon was so loud and incessant , that I could not hear something I much desired to hear , until I made a great exertion and awoke .
Parsing [sent. 17387 len. 29]: It was broad day -- eight or nine o'clock ; the storm raging , in lieu of the batteries ; and someone knocking and calling at my door .

Parsing [sent. 17401 len. 47]: Every appearance it had then presented , bore the expression of being swelled ; and the height to which the breakers rose , and , looking over one another , bore one another down , and rolled in , in interminable hosts , was most appalling .

Parsing [sent. 17405 len. 69]: One mast was broken short off , six or eight feet from the deck , and lay over the side , entangled in a maze of sail and rigging ; and all that ruin , as the ship rolled and beat -- which she did without a moment 's pause , and with a violence quite inconceivable -- beat the side as if it would stave it in .
Parsing [sent. 17406 len. 59]: Some efforts were even then being made , to cut this portion of the wreck away ; for , as the ship , which was broadside on , turned towards us in her rolling , I plainly descried her people at work with axes , especially one active figure with long curling hair , conspicuous among the rest .
Parsing [sent. 17407 len. 59]: But a great cry , which was audible even above the wind and water , rose from the shore at this moment ; the sea , sweeping over the rolling wreck , made a clean breach , and carried men , spars , casks , planks , bulwarks , heaps of such toys , into the boiling surge .
Parsing [sent. 17408 len. 27]: The second mast was yet standing , with the rags of a rent sail , and a wild confusion of broken cordage flapping to and fro .
Parsing [sent. 17409 len. 23]: The ship had struck once , the same boatman hoarsely said in my ear , and then lifted in and struck again .
Parsing [sent. 17410 len. 34]: I understood him to add that she was parting amidships , and I could readily suppose so , for the rolling and beating were too tremendous for any human work to suffer long .
Parsing [sent. 17411 len. 45]: As he spoke , there was another great cry of pity from the beach ; four men arose with the wreck out of the deep , clinging to the rigging of the remaining mast ; uppermost , the active figure with the curling hair .
Parsing [sent. 17412 len. 82]: There was a bell on board ; and as the ship rolled and dashed , like a desperate creature driven mad , now showing us the whole sweep of her deck , as she turned on her beam-ends towards the shore , now nothing but her keel , as she sprung wildly over and turned towards the sea , the bell rang ; and its sound , the knell of those unhappy men , was borne towards us on the wind .

Parsing [sent. 17795 len. 128]: Among the great beams , bulks , and ringbolts of the ship , and the emigrant-berths , and chests , and bundles , and barrels , and heaps of miscellaneous baggage -- ` lighted up , here and there , by dangling lanterns ; and elsewhere by the yellow daylight straying down a windsail or a hatchway -- were crowded groups of people , making new friendships , taking leave of one another , talking , laughing , crying , eating and drinking ; some , already settled down into the possession of their few feet of space , with their little households arranged , and tiny children established on stools , or in dwarf elbow-chairs ; others , despairing of a resting-place , and wandering disconsolately .
Parsing [sent. 17796 len. 79]: From babies who had but a week or two of life behind them , to crooked old men and women who seemed to have but a week or two of life before them ; and from ploughmen bodily carrying out soil of England on their boots , to smiths taking away samples of its soot and smoke upon their skins ; every age and occupation appeared to be crammed into the narrow compass of the ` tween decks .

Parsing [sent. 17829 len. 20]: The night had fallen on the Kentish hills when we were rowed ashore -- and fallen darkly upon me .
Parsing [sent. 17830 len. 37]: Chapter 58 Absence It was a long and gloomy night that gathered on me , haunted by the ghosts of many hopes , of many dear remembrances , many errors , many unavailing sorrows and regrets .
Parsing [sent. 17831 len. 24]: I went away from England ; not knowing , even then , how great the shock was , that I had to bear .
Parsing [sent. 17832 len. 26]: I left all who were dear to me , and went away ; and believed that I had borne it , and it was past .
Parsing [sent. 17833 len. 48]: As a man upon a field of battle will receive a mortal hurt , and scarcely know that he is struck , so I , when I was left alone with my undisciplined heart , had no conception of the wound with which it had to strive .
Parsing [sent. 17834 len. 19]: The knowledge came upon me , not quickly , but little by little , and grain by grain .
Parsing [sent. 17835 len. 14]: The desolate feeling with which I went abroad , deepened and widened hourly .
Parsing [sent. 17836 len. 19]: At first it was a heavy sense of loss and sorrow , wherein I could distinguish little else .
Parsing [sent. 17837 len. 68]: By imperceptible degrees , it became a hopeless consciousness of all that I had lost -- love , friendship , interest ; of all that had been shattered -- my first trust , my first affection , the whole airy castle of my life ; of all that remained -- a ruined blank and waste , lying wide around me , unbroken , to the dark horizon .
Parsing [sent. 17838 len. 15]: If my grief were selfish , I did not know it to be so .
Parsing [sent. 17839 len. 15]: I mourned for my child-wife , taken from her blooming world , so young .
Parsing [sent. 17840 len. 23]: I mourned for him who might have won the love and admiration of thousands , as he had won mine long ago .
Parsing [sent. 17841 len. 39]: I mourned for the broken heart that had found rest in the stormy sea ; and for the wandering remnants of the simple home , where I had heard the night-wind blowing , when I was a child .
Parsing [sent. 17842 len. 20]: From the accumulated sadness into which I fell , I had at length no hope of ever issuing again .
Parsing [sent. 17843 len. 14]: I roamed from place to place , carrying my burden with me everywhere .
Parsing [sent. 17844 len. 26]: I felt its whole weight now ; and I drooped beneath it , and I said in my heart that it could never be lightened .
Parsing [sent. 17845 len. 15]: When this despondency was at its worst , I believed that I should die .
Parsing [sent. 17846 len. 28]: Sometimes , I thought that I would like to die at home ; and actually turned back on my road , that I might get there soon .
Parsing [sent. 17847 len. 32]: At other times , I passed on farther away , -- from city to city , seeking I know not what , and trying to leave I know not what behind .
Parsing [sent. 17848 len. 26]: It is not in my power to retrace , one by one , all the weary phases of distress of mind through which I passed .
Parsing [sent. 17849 len. 37]: There are some dreams that can only be imperfectly and vaguely described ; and when I oblige myself to look back on this time of my life , I seem to be recalling such a dream .
Parsing [sent. 17850 len. 60]: I see myself passing on among the novelties of foreign towns , palaces , cathedrals , temples , pictures , castles , tombs , fantastic streets -- the old abiding places of History and Fancy -- as a dreamer might ; bearing my painful load through all , and hardly conscious of the objects as they fade before me .
Parsing [sent. 17851 len. 18]: Listlessness to everything , but brooding sorrow , was the night that fell on my undisciplined heart .
Parsing [sent. 17852 len. 16]: Let me look up from it -- as at last I did , thank Heaven !

Parsing [sent. 17854 len. 13]: For many months I travelled with this ever-darkening cloud upon my mind .

Parsing [sent. 17856 len. 24]: Sometimes , I had proceeded restlessly from place to place , stopping nowhere ; sometimes , I had lingered long in one spot .
Parsing [sent. 17857 len. 14]: I had had no purpose , no sustaining soul within me , anywhere .
Parsing [sent. 17858 len. 5]: I was in Switzerland .

Parsing [sent. 17860 len. 16]: If those awful solitudes had spoken to my heart , I did not know it .
Parsing [sent. 17861 len. 37]: I had found sublimity and wonder in the dread heights and precipices , in the roaring torrents , and the wastes of ice and snow ; but as yet , they had taught me nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 17862 len. 19]: I came , one evening before sunset , down into a valley , where I was to rest .

Parsing [sent. 17866 len. 28]: I came into the valley , as the evening sun was shining on the remote heights of snow , that closed it in , like eternal clouds .
Parsing [sent. 17867 len. 44]: The bases of the mountains forming the gorge in which the little village lay , were richly green ; and high above this gentler vegetation , grew forests of dark fir , cleaving the wintry snow-drift , wedge-like , and stemming the avalanche .

Parsing [sent. 17870 len. 33]: So did even the clustered village in the valley , with its wooden bridge across the stream , where the stream tumbled over broken rocks , and roared away among the trees .

Parsing [sent. 17874 len. 16]: Other packets had missed me , and I had received none for a long time .
Parsing [sent. 17875 len. 37]: Beyond a line or two , to say that I was well , and had arrived at such a place , I had not had fortitude or constancy to write a letter since I left home .

Parsing [sent. 17879 len. 9]: That was all she told me of herself .
Parsing [sent. 17880 len. 6]: The rest referred to me .

Parsing [sent. 17883 len. 12]: She knew how trial and emotion would exalt and strengthen it .
Parsing [sent. 17884 len. 25]: She was sure that in my every purpose I should gain a firmer and a higher tendency , through the grief I had undergone .
Parsing [sent. 17885 len. 25]: She , who so gloried in my fame , and so looked forward to its augmentation , well knew that I would labour on .
Parsing [sent. 17886 len. 17]: She knew that in me , sorrow could not be weakness , but must be strength .
Parsing [sent. 17887 len. 48]: As the endurance of my childish days had done its part to make me what I was , so greater calamities would nerve me on , to be yet better than I was ; and so , as they had taught me , would I teach others .
Parsing [sent. 17888 len. 55]: She commended me to God , who had taken my innocent darling to His rest ; and in her sisterly affection cherished me always , and was always at my side go where I would ; proud of what I had done , but infinitely prouder yet of what I was reserved to do .
Parsing [sent. 17889 len. 18]: I put the letter in my breast , and thought what had I been an hour ago !
Parsing [sent. 17890 len. 82]: When I heard the voices die away , and saw the quiet evening cloud grow dim , and all the colours in the valley fade , and the golden snow upon the mountain-tops become a remote part of the pale night sky , yet felt that the night was passing from my mind , and all its shadows clearing , there was no name for the love I bore her , dearer to me , henceforward , than ever until then .
Parsing [sent. 17891 len. 7]: I read her letter many times .
Parsing [sent. 17892 len. 8]: I wrote to her before I slept .

Parsing [sent. 17894 len. 4]: I did try .
Parsing [sent. 17895 len. 17]: In three months more , a year would have passed since the beginning of my sorrow .
Parsing [sent. 17896 len. 18]: I determined to make no resolutions until the expiration of those three months , but to try .
Parsing [sent. 17897 len. 14]: I lived in that valley , and its neighbourhood , all the time .
Parsing [sent. 17898 len. 47]: The three months gone , I resolved to remain away from home for some time longer ; to settle myself for the present in Switzerland , which was growing dear to me in the remembrance of that evening ; to resume my pen ; to work .
Parsing [sent. 17899 len. 34]: I resorted humbly whither Agnes had commended me ; I sought out Nature , never sought in vain ; and I admitted to my breast the human interest I had lately shrunk from .
Parsing [sent. 17900 len. 60]: It was not long , before I had almost as many friends in the valley as in Yarmouth : and when I left it , before the winter set in , for Geneva , and came back in the spring , their cordial greetings had a homely sound to me , although they were not conveyed in English words .
Parsing [sent. 17901 len. 10]: I worked early and late , patiently and hard .
Parsing [sent. 17902 len. 54]: I wrote a Story , with a purpose growing , not remotely , out of my experience , and sent it to Traddles , and he arranged for its publication very advantageously for me ; and the tidings of my growing reputation began to reach me from travellers whom I encountered by chance .
Parsing [sent. 17903 len. 29]: After some rest and change , I fell to work , in my old ardent way , on a new fancy , which took strong possession of me .

Parsing [sent. 17909 len. 5]: I had seen much .
Parsing [sent. 17910 len. 18]: I had been in many countries , and I hope I had improved my store of knowledge .

Parsing [sent. 17912 len. 33]: I have made it , thus far , with no purpose of suppressing any of my thoughts ; for , as I have elsewhere said , this narrative is my written memory .
Parsing [sent. 17913 len. 19]: I have desired to keep the most secret current of my mind apart , and to the last .
Parsing [sent. 17914 len. 6]: I enter on it now .
Parsing [sent. 17915 len. 34]: I can not so completely penetrate the mystery of my own heart , as to know when I began to think that I might have set its earliest and brightest hopes on Agnes .
Parsing [sent. 17916 len. 35]: I can not say at what stage of my grief it first became associated with the reflection , that , in my wayward boyhood , I had thrown away the treasure of her love .
Parsing [sent. 17917 len. 34]: I believe I may have heard some whisper of that distant thought , in the old unhappy loss or want of something never to be realized , of which I had been sensible .
Parsing [sent. 17918 len. 27]: But the thought came into my mind as a new reproach and new regret , when I was left so sad and lonely in the world .
Parsing [sent. 17919 len. 27]: If , at that time , I had been much with her , I should , in the weakness of my desolation , have betrayed this .
Parsing [sent. 17920 len. 17]: It was what I remotely dreaded when I was first impelled to stay away from England .
Parsing [sent. 17921 len. 32]: I could not have borne to lose the smallest portion of her sisterly affection ; yet , in that betrayal , I should have set a constraint between us hitherto unknown .
Parsing [sent. 17922 len. 24]: I could not forget that the feeling with which she now regarded me had grown up in my own free choice and course .
Parsing [sent. 17923 len. 31]: That if she had ever loved me with another love -- and I sometimes thought the time was when she might have done so -- I had cast it away .
Parsing [sent. 17924 len. 34]: It was nothing , now , that I had accustomed myself to think of her , when we were both mere children , as one who was far removed from my wild fancies .
Parsing [sent. 17925 len. 39]: I had bestowed my passionate tenderness upon another object ; and what I might have done , I had not done ; and what Agnes was to me , I and her own noble heart had made her .
Parsing [sent. 17926 len. 61]: In the beginning of the change that gradually worked in me , when I tried to get a better understanding of myself and be a better man , I did glance , through some indefinite probation , to a period when I might possibly hope to cancel the mistaken past , and to be so blessed as to marry her .
Parsing [sent. 17927 len. 17]: But , as time wore on , this shadowy prospect faded , and departed from me .
Parsing [sent. 17928 len. 53]: If she had ever loved me , then , I should hold her the more sacred ; remembering the confidences I had reposed in her , her knowledge of my errant heart , the sacrifice she must have made to be my friend and sister , and the victory she had won .
Parsing [sent. 17929 len. 17]: If she had never loved me , could I believe that she would love me now ?
Parsing [sent. 17930 len. 24]: I had always felt my weakness , in comparison with her constancy and fortitude ; and now I felt it more and more .
Parsing [sent. 17931 len. 34]: Whatever I might have been to her , or she to me , if I had been more worthy of her long ago , I was not now , and she was not .
Parsing [sent. 17932 len. 5]: The time was past .
Parsing [sent. 17933 len. 13]: I had let it go by , and had deservedly lost her .
Parsing [sent. 17934 len. 93]: That I suffered much in these contentions , that they filled me with unhappiness and remorse , and yet that I had a sustaining sense that it was required of me , in right and honour , to keep away from myself , with shame , the thought of turning to the dear girl in the withering of my hopes , from whom I had frivolously turned when they were bright and fresh -- which consideration was at the root of every thought I had concerning her -- is all equally true .
Parsing [sent. 17935 len. 48]: I made no effort to conceal from myself , now , that I loved her , that I was devoted to her ; but I brought the assurance home to myself , that it was now too late , and that our long-subsisting relation must be undisturbed .
Parsing [sent. 17936 len. 60]: I had thought , much and often , of my Dora 's shadowing out to me what might have happened , in those years that were destined not to try us ; I had considered how the things that never happen , are often as much realities to us , in their effects , as those that are accomplished .
Parsing [sent. 17937 len. 37]: The very years she spoke of , were realities now , for my correction ; and would have been , one day , a little later perhaps , though we had parted in our earliest folly .
Parsing [sent. 17938 len. 36]: I endeavoured to convert what might have been between myself and Agnes , into a means of making me more self-denying , more resolved , more conscious of myself , and my defects and errors .
Parsing [sent. 17939 len. 22]: Thus , through the reflection that it might have been , I arrived at the conviction that it could never be .
Parsing [sent. 17940 len. 34]: These , with their perplexities and inconsistencies , were the shifting quicksands of my mind , from the time of my departure to the time of my return home , three years afterwards .

Parsing [sent. 17946 len. 13]: Chapter 59 Return I landed in London on a wintry autumn evening .

Parsing [sent. 17951 len. 14]: For some changes in the fortunes of my friends , I was prepared .

Parsing [sent. 18584 len. 24]: When it 's fine , and we go out for a walk in the evening , the streets abound in enjoyment for us .
Parsing [sent. 18585 len. 122]: We look into the glittering windows of the jewellers ' shops ; and I show Sophy which of the diamond-eyed serpents , coiled up on white satin rising grounds , I would give her if I could afford it ; and Sophy shows me which of the gold watches that are capped and jewelled and engine-turned , and possessed of the horizontal lever - escape-movement , and all sorts of things , she would buy for me if she could afford it ; and we pick out the spoons and forks , fish-slices , butter-knives , and sugar-tongs , we should both prefer if we could both afford it ; and really we go away as if we had got them !
Parsing [sent. 18586 len. 42]: Then , when we stroll into the squares , and great streets , and see a house to let , sometimes we look up at it , and say , how would THAT do , if I was made a judge ?
Parsing [sent. 18587 len. 45]: And we parcel it out -- such a room for us , such rooms for the girls , and so forth ; until we settle to our satisfaction that it would do , or it would n't do , as the case may be .
Parsing [sent. 18588 len. 49]: Sometimes , we go at half-price to the pit of the theatre - the very smell of which is cheap , in my opinion , at the money -- and there we thoroughly enjoy the play : which Sophy believes every word of , and so do I .
Parsing [sent. 18589 len. 45]: In walking home , perhaps we buy a little bit of something at a cook 's - shop , or a little lobster at the fishmongers , and bring it here , and make a splendid supper , chatting about what we have seen .

Parsing [sent. 18633 len. 54]: After some conversation among these gentlemen , from which I might have supposed that there was nothing in the world to be legitimately taken into account but the supreme comfort of prisoners , at any expense , and nothing on the wide earth to be done outside prison-doors , we began our inspection .

Parsing [sent. 18635 len. 72]: I said aside , to Traddles , that I wondered whether it occurred to anybody , that there was a striking contrast between these plentiful repasts of choice quality , and the dinners , not to say of paupers , but of soldiers , sailors , labourers , the great bulk of the honest , working community ; of whom not one man in five hundred ever dined half so well .
Parsing [sent. 18636 len. 55]: But I learned that the ` system ' required high living ; and , in short , to dispose of the system , once for all , I found that on that head and on all others , ` the system ' put an end to all doubts , and disposed of all anomalies .
Parsing [sent. 18637 len. 22]: Nobody appeared to have the least idea that there was any other system , but THE system , to be considered .
Parsing [sent. 18638 len. 35]: As we were going through some of the magnificent passages , I inquired of Mr. Creakle and his friends what were supposed to be the main advantages of this all-governing and universally over-riding system ?
Parsing [sent. 18639 len. 44]: I found them to be the perfect isolation of prisoners -- so that no one man in confinement there , knew anything about another ; and the reduction of prisoners to a wholesome state of mind , leading to sincere contrition and repentance .
Parsing [sent. 18640 len. 74]: Now , it struck me , when we began to visit individuals in their cells , and to traverse the passages in which those cells were , and to have the manner of the going to chapel and so forth , explained to us , that there was a strong probability of the prisoners knowing a good deal about each other , and of their carrying on a pretty complete system of intercourse .

Parsing [sent. 18792 len. 25]: Chapter 62 A Light Shines on My Way The year came round to Christmas-time , and I had been at home above two months .
